For this reason, they were classified as disbelievers (kuffār) and God did not classify them as polytheists (mushrikīn), even though they are the ones who cause humans to commit polytheism. When humans commit polytheism, the jinn disavow the polytheist, as God Almighty said: <<كَمَثَلِ الشَّيْطَانِ إِذْ قَالَ لِلْإِنْسَانِ اكْفُرْ>> (Like the example of Satan when he said to man, "Disbelieve"), which is the devil's revelation to his protégé, so that he may argue with falsehood against the People of Truth. When the man disbelieves, the devil says to him: <<إِنِّي بَرِيءٌ مِنْكَ إِنِّي أَخَافُ اللَّهَ رَبَّ الْعَالَمِينَ>> (Indeed, I am disassociated from you; indeed, I fear Allah, Lord of the worlds).

Thus, the devil is described as fearing God, but on behalf of that human, not on his own behalf. The devil's fear is for the one who accepted his temptation, not for himself, just as the Prophets, peace be upon them, fear for their nations on the Day of Resurrection, not for themselves. The reason for the devil's lack of fear for himself is his knowledge that he is among the People of Monotheism (ahl al-tawḥīd). For this reason, he said: <<فَبِعِزَّتِكَ لَأُغْوِيَنَّهُمْ أَجْمَعِينَ>> (By Your might, I will surely mislead them all). He swore by Him Almighty, knowing his Lord, as if he saw The Real, that He had known from the formation of man his acceptance of everything cast upon him.

When he asked for that, God answered his request and commanded him with what he used to mislead mankind, saying to him: <<اذْهَبْ>> (Go)—meaning, go to what you asked of Me. He mentioned his recompense, and the recompense of those humans who followed him. The devil's recompense was that God returned him to his origin from which He created him. The recompense of the human who followed him was likewise. However, the human's recompense prevailed over Iblīs's recompense, for God made their recompense only Hell (Jahannam), and in it is the torment of Iblīs. For Hell is entirely cold; there is nothing fiery in it. Thus, it is a greater torment for Iblīs than for his follower. This was because Iblīs sought to make others wretched, so his intention rebounded upon him for what he aimed at. This is an alert from The Real to us that we should not intend the occurrence of what leads to misery for anyone, for that is a Divine Attribute.

For this reason, God made clear the path of guidance (al-hudā) from the path of misguidance (al-ḍalālah). The upright servant is the one who is upon the straight path of his Lord, even though the devil is under his Lord's command in His saying: <<اذْهَبْ وَاسْتَفْزِزْ وَأَجْلِبْ وَشَارِكْهُمْ وَوَعِدْهُمْ>> (Go, and incite, and assault, and share with them, and promise them). These are all Divine commands. If they had been initiated by God, Iblīs would not have been wretched. But since it was an answer to his saying: <<فَبِعِزَّتِكَ لَأُغْوِيَنَّهُمْ أَجْمَعِينَ * وَلَأَحْتَنِكَنَّ ذُرِّيَّتَهُ>> (By Your might, I will surely mislead them all, and I will surely lead his descendants by the reins), he became wretched by it, just as the obligated one suffers hardship in what he requested of obligation. For the Law includes what was revealed initially and what was revealed in response to a request.

Were it not for the Mercy (al-Raḥmah) that encompasses all things, the matter would be as it appeared in general.

When I restricted this connection, I fell into a light sleep (ghafwah), and I saw in a true vision (al-mubashshirah) the recitation of: <<شَرَعَ لَكُمْ مِنَ الدِّينِ مَا وَصَّى بِهِ نُوحًا وَالَّذِي أَوْحَيْنَا إِلَيْكَ وَمَا وَصَّيْنَا بِهِ إِبْرَاهِيمَ وَمُوسَى وَعِيسَى أَنْ أَقِيمُوا الدِّينَ وَلَا تَتَفَرَّقُوا فِيهِ كَبُرَ عَلَى الْمُشْرِكِينَ مَا تَدْعُوهُمْ إِلَيْهِ>> (He has ordained for you of religion what He enjoined upon Noah and that which We have revealed to you, [O Muhammad], and what We enjoined upon Abraham and Moses and Jesus—to establish the religion and not be divided therein. Difficult for the polytheists is that to which you invite them). This refers to Unity (al-Waḥdah).

Unity is vast in rulings, for <<لِلَّهِ الْأَسْمَاءُ الْحُسْنَى>> (To Allah belong the Most Beautiful Names), and every Name is a sign of an intelligible reality that is not the other. The faces of the world in its emergence from non-existence to Existence are numerous, seeking those Names—meaning the named realities—even though the Essence (al-ʿayn) is one, just as the world, insofar as it is the world, is one, yet it is numerous in rulings and individuals.

Then, the verse was recited to me: <<اللَّهُ يَجْتَبِي إِلَيْهِ مَنْ يَشَاءُ وَيَهْدِي إِلَيْهِ مَنْ يُنِيبُ>> (Allah chooses for Himself whom He wills and guides to Himself whoever turns back [to Him]). No attribute or state of wretchedness was mentioned here; rather, the matter was mentioned between selection (ijtibā’) and guidance (hidāyah). Then it was said to me: "From the knowledge of guidance and selection, one knows what the Prophets brought." Both matters belong to Him. Whoever He selects (ijtabā) to Himself, He brings him to Himself and does not entrust him to his own soul. Whoever He guides (hadā) to Himself, He clarifies the path leading to Him so that he may be felicitous, and leaves him to his own view: <<إِمَّا شَاكِرًا وَإِمَّا كَفُورًا * إِنَّا هَدَيْنَاهُ السَّبِيلَ>> (Indeed, We guided him to the way, whether grateful or ungrateful).

Since God Almighty came in this general verse and did not mention a name or entity for wretchedness, but mentioned selection and guidance—which here means clarification—and made both matters belong to Him, we know that the ruling belongs to the Mercy (al-Raḥmah) that <<وَسِعَتْ كُلَّ شَيْءٍ>> (encompasses all things).

The polytheist (al-mushrik) was only mentioned because what he was invited to was difficult for him, because he was invited from a single aspect (Unity), while he witnesses the multiplicity of his existence, which The Real made a proof for him in the saying: "He who knows himself knows his Lord."

He did not know himself except as one in many, or many in one. Thus, he does not know his Lord except through the form of his knowledge of himself. For this reason, the call of the Real (الحق) to absolute Oneness (الأحدية) without considering other aspects became difficult for him. That is because the polytheist (المشرك) did not understand God's intention in that address. When the Real (الحق) knew that this was difficult for him, He was gentle with him and made the matter dependent upon Him, exalted is He, between election (اجتباء) and guidance (هداية). So, he associated partners (شرك) through election and guidance, and affirmed Oneness (وحد) through the phrase 'to Him' in both matters, out of gentleness and familiarity (أنس) toward him, so that he may know that He is the Forgiving, the Merciful toward those who transgress against themselves.

And when Iblis saw God's favor (منة الله) flowing throughout the cosmos (العالم), he yearned for God's mercy from the perspective of favor, not from the perspective of Divine necessity (الوجوب الإلهي). So he worshipped Him absolutely, not conditionally. Thus, in whatever direction he turned, he did not depart from the Real (حق), just as the Law (الشرع) which He enjoined upon those mentioned in this verse has diverse rulings, some abrogating others, yet all were commanded to uphold it and not to be divided concerning the division that is inherent within it. Thus, He calls through multiplicity (كثرة) to a single Essence (عين واحدة), or through Unity (وحدة) to multiple realities (حقائق كثيرة)—say whatever you wish, provided it does not change the meaning.

> So all things, in the ruling of Existence (الوجود),
> Are like all things, in the very Essence of Witnessing (الشهود).
> So that His mercy may encompass all creatures,
> And the signs of denial may become manifest.
> Thus He is the All-Merciful (رحمان) toward him
> Who claims to be wretched or happy.
> This one is in the abode of Hell,
> That one is in the Gardens of Eternity.
> And God, exalted is He in His Essence (ذاته),
> Is beyond confinement and limits.

This Connection (الوصل) is wide in scope. It contains the knowledge of the commands specific only to the Lawgiver (الشارع), who is the Messenger; and the knowledge of what is guarded against by means of the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية); and the knowledge of the Sovereign of the Kingdom (مالك الملك), the meaning signified by the Name *al-Ilāh* (God), and His description by Oneness (الأحدية) in His saying: "There is no god except one God." And its attribution to the pronoun, such as *Ilāhukum* (Your God), and to the manifest, such as *Ilāhu Mūsā* (The God of Moses) and *Ilāh al-Nās* (The God of mankind)—is the ruling the same, or does it change with the change of attribution or description? And the knowledge of Lordship (الربوبية) and the fact that it never comes from God without restriction; and the knowledge of inspiration (الإلهام) and the variation of the Name applied to it through the paths from which it comes.

### The Second Connection

from this Chapter, which is connected to the Second Station (المنزل الثاني) of the Stations mentioned in this Book. It includes sciences, among them the knowledge of distinguishing between that by which the perception (الإدراك) of things occurs, and that by which only itself is perceived specifically. And the knowledge of how the seed (البزرة), the date-stone (النواة), and the grain (الحبة) store what manifests from them when sown in the earth, and how they indicate the knowledge of the cosmos's (العالم) emergence from the Unseen (الغيب) into the Visible (الشهادة). This is because the seed does not yield what the Real (الحق) stored within it until after it is buried in the earth, whereupon it splits open, revealing what it stored: a stalk, leaves, and seeds like itself; from the date-stone, date-stones; from the grain, grains; and from the seed, seeds. Thus, its essence (عينها) appears in much of what emerged from it. From this, you know what the grain is from which the cosmos emerged, and what it yielded by its own essence (بذاتها) in the manifest grains, and why what appeared from it relies on something other than the essences of the grains themselves. Were it not for what is stored within it potentially (بالقوة), it would not have appeared actually (بالفعل). Know this. And all of this is from the Treasuries of Generosity (خزائن الجود). It includes the knowledge of the absolute command in His saying: <<اعْمَلُوا ما شِئْتُمْ>> (Do what you will), and the command restricted to a specific action, and the variation of the formulations therein.

### [Evil is not from God]

It includes the knowledge of attributing evils (الشرور) to other than God, because they are intelligible to the knower (العالم).

Thus, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "And evil is not attributed to You."

Thus, he affirmed it in its essence (عينه) but negated its attribution to the Real (الحق), indicating that evil is not a thing (شيء) but rather non-existence (عدم). For if it were a thing, it would be in the hand of the Real, since <<بِيَدِهِ مَلَكُوتُ كُلِّ شَيْءٍ>> (In His Hand is the dominion of all things) and He is <<خالِقُ كُلِّ شَيْءٍ>> (The Creator of all things). He has already shown you what He created by means of an instrument and without an instrument, by *Kun* (Be!), by His Hand, by His two Hands, and by hands. He distinguished, informed, decreed, brought into existence, gathered, and unified, saying: 'I' (إني), 'We' (نحن), 'I' (أنا), and 'Indeed We' (إنا). For this reason, it was difficult for the polytheists (المشركين), because the concept of 'We' is not the same as the concept of 'I'. And the address came with 'to Him,' thus affirming Oneness (وحد), but they did not perceive an essence (عين) for the plural, so that became difficult for them. And the *nūn* of majesty (in 'We') when referring to the One is the saying of one who has no knowledge of the realities (الحقائق) nor of the Arabic language.

It includes the knowledge of the darkness of ignorance (ظلمة الجهل) when it settles in the heart, blinding it from perceiving the realities (الحقائق) by the perception of which one is called a knower (عالما). The Exalted said: <<أَ ومن كانَ مَيْتاً فَأَحْيَيْناهُ وجَعَلْنا لَهُ نُوراً يَمْشِي به في النَّاسِ كَمَنْ مَثَلُهُ في الظُّلُماتِ>> (Is he who was dead and We gave him life and made for him a light by which to walk among the people, like one whose likeness is in the darknesses?). He meant knowledge (العلم) and ignorance (الجهل). Not everything that is perceived, but by which one does not perceive, is darkness. For if the light is stronger than the light of the eye, a person perceives it but does not perceive *by* it. For this reason, the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, mentioned concerning God that His veil (حجابه) is Light (النور). Thus, Unveiling (الكشف) only occurs by the light that is commensurate with the light of the eye. Do you not see that bats only appear in the light that is commensurate with the light of their eyes, which is the light of twilight?

It includes the knowledge of ambiguities (الشبهات), which is every known thing in which an aspect of the Real (الحق) appears and an aspect of other than the Real. Thus, in provisions, there is what is clearly lawful (حلال بين) and clearly unlawful (حرام بين), and between them are ambiguities (مشتبهات) which many people do not know. Whoever perceives them should pause until their ruling becomes clear to him, either by attaching them to the lawful or by attaching them to the unlawful. He should not proceed with them as long as they remain ambiguous in his regard. For in reality (في نفس الأمر), they belong purely to one of the two sides; they only become ambiguous to the legally responsible person (المكلف) due to the conflict of legal proofs concerning them in his view. And in intelligible matters, such as the actions appearing at the hands of creatures: there is an aspect indicating they are for God, and an aspect indicating they are for the creature upon whom they appeared in the Visible World (الشهادة), yet in reality, they belong purely to one of the two sides. Likewise, magic (السحر) and miracle (المعجزة). Magic has an aspect toward the Real, so it resembles the Real, and an aspect toward other than the Real, so it resembles falsehood (الباطل). It is derived from *al-siḥr*, which is the mixing of light and darkness, so it does not belong purely to either side.

When the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, was bewitched, it was made to appear to him in his imagination (يخيل إليه) that he had approached his wives when he had not. So he approached them truly in the essence of Imagination (الخيال), but did not approach them truly in the essence of the Senses (الحس). This is according to what was ruled upon him, and this is a great matter. If someone wishes to nullify magic, he looks at what the sorcerer has tied and gives to each knot a word by which he unties it, whatever it may be. If he falls short of the words, the effect remains upon him, for it is only removed by untying the whole, and this is a Divine science.

For the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, says: "Indeed, the Holy Spirit breathed into my heart."

And *nafth* (breathing/spitting) is only wind with saliva; this is necessary so that it may encompass. Just as He gave him from His Spirit with its wind, He gave him from his natural constitution with his saliva. Thus, He combined everything for him in *nafth*, unlike *nafk* (blowing), which is pure wind. Likewise, magic (السحر) is the lung (الرئة), which provides the hot outgoing air and the cold incoming air. It contains the two forces, the attractive and the repulsive. It was named *siḥr* because it accepts both hot and cold breath, and because of the moisture within it, it does not burn up from accepting the hot breath. For this reason, the breath exits with dampness, which is like the saliva present in the *nafth* breathed by the Spirit into the heart and by the sorcerer into the knot.

It includes the knowledge of the difference between one who desires the expansion of God's mercy upon His servants, both obedient and disobedient, and one who desires the removal of God's mercy from some of His servants—the latter being he who restricts God's mercy, which <<وَسِعَتْ كُلَّ شَيْءٍ>> (encompasses all things), yet does not restrict it upon himself. The possessor of this attribute, were it not that God's mercy preceded His wrath, would be among those whom God's mercy would never reach.

### [God described Himself as being with everything]

Know that when God, the Exalted, brought things into existence from an origin that is His very Essence (عينه), He described Himself as being *with* everything, wherever that thing might be, in order to preserve it by means of the form within it, ensuring the continuation of that species in Existence (الوجود). Thus, the multiplicity of forms appeared from a single form, which is its essence (عينها) by definition, but different from it individually (بالشخص), just as we said concerning grains originating from a single grain. It is a treasury from the Treasuries of Generosity (خزائن الجود) for what resembles it and for what is necessarily connected to it, even if it differs from it in form. For the treasury stores treasuries, and stores what is stored within those treasuries. Even if what emerges is not in its form, there must be a common element (جامع) that unites them, the most manifest of which is corporeality in the grain, the leaf, the fruit, the body, the branches, and the roots. This is witnessed by every eye, originating from the single grain or the single seed, in addition to the likenesses.

The Perfect Ones (الكامل) among the Caliphs (الخلفاء) are like the grains from the grain, the date-stones from the date-stone, and the seeds from the seed. So every grain yields what the original grain yielded, due to its specific possession of the form in perfection, and it is distinguished only by its individual person (بالشخص) specifically. As for the rest of the cosmos apart from the Caliphs, they have from the Real (الحق) what the leaves, branches, flowers, and roots have from the date-stone, the seed, or the grain. From this, the superiority of the Human Caliph (الإنسان الخليفة) over the animalistic human (الإنسان الحيوان)—who is closest in resemblance to the Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل)—and then over all other creatures, is known. Understand what we have explained, for it is from the core essence of the Knowledge of God (العلم بالله) granted by Unveiling (الكشف) and Witnessing (الشهود).

If you ask: "How do I know about myself whether I am one of the Perfect Ones (الكمل) or one of the animalistic beings called human?" We say: Yes, concerning what you asked, know that you do not know that you are upon the Form unless you know the saying of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: "The believer is the mirror of his brother."

So the believer sees himself in the mirror of his brother, and the other sees himself in him. This only occurs in the Presence (حضرة) of the Divine Name *al-Mu'min* (The Giver of Security). And He said: <<إِنَّمَا الْمُؤْمِنُونَ إِخْوَةٌ>> (The believers are but brothers). And He said: "The believer is many through his brother, just as he is one by himself." Thus, it is known that all the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية) are brothers, like the believers: <<فَأَصْلِحُوا بَيْنَ أَخَوَيْكُمْ>> (So make reconciliation between your two brothers)—meaning when they conflict, like *al-Mu'izz* (The Giver of Honor) and *al-Mudhill* (The Humiliator), or *al-Dārr* (The Harmer) and *al-Nāfiʿ* (The Benefiter). As for the Names other than the opposing ones, they are brothers <<عَلى‏ سُرُرٍ مُتَقابِلِينَ>> (on couches facing one another). And nothing reconciles between the Names except the Name *al-Rabb* (The Lord), for He is the Reconciler, and the believer is a mirror in that capacity. Whoever sees himself thus knows that he is one of the Caliphs (الخلفاء) by virtue of the Form he has seen.

But this animalistic human (الإنسان الحيوان) has no mirror, even if he has the shape of a mirror, for it lacks polish and smoothness; rust and tarnish have covered it, so it does not accept the image of the viewer. It is only called a mirror by virtue of the vision. Therefore, if the Real (الحق) establishes you in absolute Servitude (العبودة المطلقة) which contains no Lordship (ربوبية), then you are truly His Caliph. For the one who appoints a deputy has no authority whatsoever over what he has delegated to his deputy. So He appointed him as Caliph in Servitude (العبودة), and Lordship (الربوبية) has no share in it, because the Caliph has become independent in it by an essential independence. He is in God's Hand and in God's Dominion. The Exalted said: <<سُبْحانَ الَّذِي أَسْرى‏ بِعَبْدِهِ>> (Exalted is He who took His servant by night). Thus, He made him a pure servant (عبدا محضا) and stripped him of everything, even the Night Journey (الإسراء), making him one who was journeyed *with*, and He did not attribute the journey to him. For if He had said: "Exalted is He who called His servant to journey to Him or to see His signs, and he journeyed," then the servant would have a claim. But the Station (المقام) prevented that, making him compelled, having no share of Lordship (الربوبية) in any action.

### The Third Connection

from the Treasuries of Generosity (خزائن الجود) concerning what is appropriate to it and related to the Third Station (المنزل الثالث). It includes the knowledge of the command that occurs in response to a question, for commands are either initiated spontaneously or occur as a response. It includes the knowledge of the Ipseity (الهوية) and the difference between Ipseity, Absolute Oneness (الأحدية), and Relative Unity (الواحدية). It includes the knowledge of what the designated meaning of *Allah* is, why He is described by attributes but is not Himself an attribute, and whether the reality of Ipseity (حقيقة الهوية) resembles anything in the cosmos (العالم) in any aspect, or if it has no resemblance in any aspect. And the form by which the Name *Allah* is restricted when it occurs with contextual indicators. It includes the knowledge of whether the manifestation of the cosmos (العالم) is an essential manifestation of the Essence of the Real (ذات الحق), or due to a ruling established in Divine Knowledge (العلم الإلهي), or manifested by the ruling of choice (الاختيار), so that the cosmos belongs to what it is attributed to, allowing the Levels (المراتب) to become distinct. It includes the knowledge of negating the counterpart (المماثل), which, if proven, would validate the cosmos existing between them. He is not a father to us, nor are we sons; rather, He is the Lord (الرب) and we are the servants (العبيد). He seeks us as servants, and we seek Him as Master.

> He is exalted above definition by thought and report,
> Just as He is majestic beyond the judgment of insight and sight.
> We have nothing of Him except what He intends,
> In every state, through indications and lessons.
> Know that I have not realized anything other than Him,
> And know that I have not known anything except humanity.
> Therefore, the All-Merciful (الرحمن) forbade, in His revelation
> Upon the tongue of the Messenger of God, contemplation of His Essence (ذاته).
> So He said: <<ولا تَقْفُ الذي لست عالما>> (And do not pursue that of which you have no knowledge),
> Lest those who contemplate be in danger.
> For the All-Merciful <<لَمْ يُولَدْ>> (was not born) in knowledge, nor did He <<لَمْ يَلِدْ>> (beget)
> In existence. So realize what He forbade and what He commanded.

Since it was not possible for God to create among His creation a power in any existent being by which that being could encompass God in knowledge, due to that power's dependence upon Him, His Majesty's (جلاله) true nature is not perceived by intellect, nor is the true nature of His Essence (ذاته) perceived by sight when He manifests (تجلى) to His servants, wherever He manifests. Thus, He, the Exalted, is the Manifesting One (المتجلي) who is not perceived by the perception by which He perceives Himself, neither by knowledge nor by vision. Therefore, a person should not pursue the knowledge of that which he already knows he cannot attain. Al-Siddīq (Abu Bakr), may God be pleased with him, said: "The inability to perceive perception is itself perception." So, if one only perceives through inability, how can the perceiver be described as having attained Him?

> Everything in which there is coupling and pairing
> Is intended for the masters of argumentation.
> When He produces me, I produce Him;
> Thus, you see us in coupling and production.
> So what appears from our states
> Is between clarity and integration.
> Just as we are by Him, so is He by us;
> Indeed, the essence of constriction is the essence of expansion.

### [That it is from the Treasuries of Generosity for man to know that there is no common element between Servitude and Lordship]

Know that it is from the Treasuries of Generosity (خزائن الجود) that a person knows that there is no common element (جامع) between Servitude (العبودة) and Lordship (الربوبية) in any aspect whatsoever, and that they are the most intensely opposed things. For even if two similar things are opposed, they share in the attributes of the self. Blackness and whiteness, though opposed, cannot be combined. Motion and rest, though opposed, cannot be combined. The common element for blackness and whiteness is color; the common element for motion and rest is being (الكون); and the common element for contingent beings (الأكوان) and colors is accidentality. Thus, every two opposites, even if opposed or different in the cosmos (العالم), must have a common element in which they meet, except for the servant (العبد) and the Lord (الرب). For neither one ever meets the other in any matter whatsoever. The servant is he who has no aspect of Lordship (الربوبية) in him, and the Lord is He who has no aspect of Servitude (العبودية) in Him. The Lord and the servant never meet. The utmost reach of the person of illusion (صاحب الوهم) is to combine the Lord and the servant in Existence (الوجود), but that is not a common element. For by 'common element' I do not mean the mere utterance of words, but rather the attribution of the meaning to each one to the same degree as its attribution to the other. This is not found in the existence attributed to the Lord and the existence attributed to the servant. For the existence of the Lord is His Essence (عينه), while the existence of the servant is a ruling (حكم) passed upon the servant. As for his essence (عينه), he may be existent or non-existent, and the definition (الحد) is the same in both states regarding his essence. Therefore, his existence is not his essence, while the existence of the Lord is His Essence.

Thus, the servant should not stand in a station (مقام) from which he smells the fragrances of Lordship (ربوبية), for that is falsehood and the essence of ignorance. The possessor of such a station has not attained the Station of Servitude (مقام العبودة) as it is in reality. I will only add: he should not smell the fragrance of Lordship except within himself, and he should not be heedless of witnessing his Servitude (عبودته). As for others, they may attribute Lordship to him because of the manifestation of its effects they see upon him. That belongs to God, not to him. In himself, he is contrary to what appears to the cosmos from him, for it is impossible that no effect of Lordship should appear upon him.

If the disciple knows the Shaykh to be of this rank, God has opened up to that disciple what contains his happiness, for he strips himself toward the side of the Real (الحق) just as the Shaykh stripped himself. He knew this from him and relied upon God, not upon the Shaykh. He remains observing the Shaykh regarding the state (الحال) that God causes to flow through him concerning that disciple, whether it be a speech commanding or forbidding him, or knowledge that benefits him. The disciple takes it from God upon the tongue of this Shaykh. The disciple knows in himself concerning the Shaykh what the Shaykh knows concerning himself: that he is the locus for the flow of the rulings of Lordship (أحكام الربوبية). Thus, even if the Shaykh were lost, his absence would not be so significant to that disciple, due to his knowledge of his Shaykh's state.

This is like Abu Bakr al-Siddīq with the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, when the Messenger of God died. No one remained but was agitated and said what should not be heard, testifying on that day to his own deficiency and lack of knowledge concerning the Messenger he followed, except for Abu Bakr. His state did not change because of his knowledge of what was there and what the matter truly was. So he ascended the pulpit and recited: <<وما مُحَمَّدٌ إِلَّا رَسُولٌ قَدْ خَلَتْ من قَبْلِهِ الرُّسُلُ أَ فَإِنْ ماتَ أَوْ قُتِلَ انْقَلَبْتُمْ عَلى‏ أَعْقابِكُمْ>> (Muhammad is no more than a Messenger; Messengers have passed away before him. If he dies or is killed, will you turn back on your heels?) [Q 3:144]. Those whose judgment and concern had been overcome retreated, and people then recognized the superiority of Abu Bakr over the community, and he deserved the Imamate and precedence. So those who pledged allegiance to him did not do so in vain. And none held back from his allegiance except one who was ignorant of him, just as he was ignorant of the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, or one who was in a state of contemplation regarding the matter, or one who offered an interpretation. For the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, testified to his superiority over the community during his lifetime, due to the secret (السر) that settled in his breast, and the ruling of that secret manifested on that day. And that was nothing other than what we mentioned: the fulfillment of the Station of Servitude (مقام العبودة) such that he did not neglect any part of it, neither concerning himself nor concerning the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him.

Thus, Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, knew that Abu Bakr al-Siddīq was with the One who called him—namely, God, the Exalted—only by virtue of the ruling that he saw what the Real (الحق), glorified is He, addressed him with upon the tongue of His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, in every address he heard from him, and indeed, from everyone who addressed him. The Real (الحق) had taught him within himself the measure of what to accept from His address and what to reject. We hope, God willing, that this is our station, and that He does not make it a false claim. For I have tasted this station (المقام) with an unmixed tasting (ذوقا لا مزاج فيه); I know it from myself, and I have not heard it from anyone who preceded me in time other than Abu Bakr al-Siddīq, except for one of the men mentioned in Al-Qushayri's *Risala*, from whom it is related that he said: "If all people gathered to lower my soul to the rank of baseness that it holds for me, they would not be able to." This belongs only to one who has tasted the flavor of Servitude (العبودية); it cannot belong to anyone else. When a group of the Companions testified to me that I was upon the footstep of Abu Bakr al-Siddīq, I knew that it was nothing but the Station of Pure Servitude (مقام العبودة المحضة). To God belongs all praise and thanks for that. May God make this his description in himself, in this world and the Hereafter, for anyone who looks at me even once in his life. Likewise, the author of *Al-Bayāḍ wa al-Sawād* (The White and the Black) related in his book from one of the men that he said: "The Gnostic (العارف) is black-faced in this world and the Hereafter." If he alludes to himself, he is the possessor of the Station (صاحب المقام). If this is stumbled upon without it being his description, then he has fulfilled the right of what God created humanity for, because He said: <<وما خَلَقْتُ الْجِنَّ والْإِنْسَ إِلَّا لِيَعْبُدُونِ>> (And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me)—meaning outwardly and inwardly. Thus, He did not grant them a foothold in Lordship (الربوبية). This is how a person should be in himself, fulfilling the right of what he was created for. If he does not do so, he is an animalistic human (إنسان حيوان). And God <<يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (speaks the Truth, and He guides to the Way).

### The Fourth Connection

from the Treasuries of Generosity (خزائن الجود) concerning what is appropriate to it and related to the Fourth Station (المنزل الرابع). We have mentioned the sciences it contains in its proper place in Chapter 273. Know that it is from the Treasuries of Generosity that a person must know by tasting (ذوقا): the knowledge of what he is independent of, and what he is not independent of. That is, to know that the highest degree of independence (الغني) for the servant is to be independent of everything other than God by means of God. This is not, in our view, a praiseworthy station (مقام محمود) on the Path. For in that, there is an affirmation of value for what is other than the Real (الحق), and a distinction from his own self. The possessor of the Station of Servitude (مقام العبودة) finds, through his tasting (ذوقه), that everything other than God is a servant just like him, with no difference. He sees that everything other than God is a locus for the flow of the Real's (الحق) definitions to him, so he is in need of everything. Yet, he is only in need of God, and he does not see that anything is in need of him in himself. Even if God benefits people through his hands, he is personally detached from that. He sees that every name by which a thing is named, which yields him a benefit, is a Name of God, except that he does not apply it to that thing as a legal ruling or out of Divine etiquette. The Divine Name *al-Mughnī* (The Enricher) is the one that grants the servant the Station of Independence (مقام الغني) by whatever He wills, by which his soul becomes independent.

And independence (الغني), even if it is by God, is the locus of blind temptation (الفتنة العمياء), for it gives rise to arrogance toward God's servants and causes ignorance of the cosmos and of oneself, as the companion of Junayd said: "And who is the cosmos that it should be mentioned alongside God?" Although the one who said this statement was a possessor of a spiritual state (صاحب حال) and knew that God only addressed His servants according to the measure of acceptance He placed in them for knowing His address, so His address varies to broaden and generalize the matter. God did not create the cosmos upon a single footing except in one thing, which is need (الافتقار). Need (الفقر) is essential (ذاتي) to it, and independence (الغني) is an accidental matter (أمر عرضي) for it. The one who lacks knowledge is veiled from his essential matter by the accidental matter. But the realized knower (العالم المحقق) always witnesses the essential matter of everything, including himself, perpetually, in this world and the Hereafter. Thus, he remains a poor servant (عبدا فقيرا) under the command of his Master, never becoming independent of his Lord in himself.

Do you not see that prostration (السجود) to God, the Exalted, is universal among all creatures except for this human species? For prostration to God did not encompass him universally. Yet, prostration has encompassed him, for he is never without prostrating, because prostration is essential (ذاتي) to him, as he is a poor, needy servant who suffers. Need (الحاجة) is attached to him and established. So he either prostrates to God, or he prostrates to other than God, based on the understanding that this prostration is, in his view, either for God or for one who brings him closer to God in his claim. This illusion (التوهم) is necessary. For this reason, God showed mercy to His servants by what He obligated and commanded them to do, such as prostrating to Adam, to the Kaaba, and to the Rock of Jerusalem, knowing what He placed in His servants: that some of them would prostrate to creatures without God's command. So He commanded those whom He commanded, whether angel or human, to prostrate to a creature, and made that an act of worship (عبادة) by which one draws near to Him, glorified is He, so that the questioning on the Day of Resurrection concerning those who prostrated to other than God without God's command might be lessened. Thus, the Real (الحق) has no claim against them except concerning the command. He asks them: "Who commanded you to do that?" He does not say to them: "It is not permissible to prostrate to a creature," for He has legislated that concerning a specific creature, both sensually and imaginatively. Like the dream of Joseph, peace be upon him, who saw the sun, the moon, and eleven stars prostrating to him. These were his father, his aunt, and his brothers. What he perceived imaginatively (خيالا) occurred sensually (حسا). The story is well-known, recited as Quran in a stellar form. When they entered upon him, <<خَرُّوا لَهُ سُجَّداً>> (they fell down prostrating to him). Joseph, peace be upon him, said to his father: <<هذا تَأْوِيلُ>> (This is the interpretation)—meaning the outcome—<<رُؤْيايَ من قَبْلُ قَدْ جَعَلَها رَبِّي حَقًّا>> (of my vision of old. My Lord has made it true)—meaning true in the senses, though it was true in the imagination (الخيال) in the realm of the vision. Thus, there is nothing there but the Real (حق). And God would not perpetuate punishment upon one who brought forth the Real (حق).

For when God divided the Real (الحق) into what is commanded and what is forbidden, the Real intended to distinguish between the one who performed the commanded act and the one who performed the forbidden act, so that the obedient might be distinguished from the disobedient, and the Levels (المراتب) might be differentiated. When everyone knows his measure and what he brought forth, mercy encompasses all, each category in its station, based on the fact that he only came with the Real (حق), even if it was forbidden. For the slanderer possesses an imaginative reality (حق خيالي), not a sensual reality (حق حسي). The slanderer does not slander until the slander and the slandered person are present in his imagination (خياله), and he establishes it in the form of what he slandered him with. Thus, it is an imaginative representation, exactly like the image in a dream. He reported it as an imaginative reality, but he remained silent about defining it as such to the listener, so the listener took it as a sensual reality. God intended the distinction (الفرقان) between the classes and levels (مراتب) of the cosmos. Therefore, He followed the possessor of this description with punishment for that, or with forgiveness, whichever He willed. Because among these disobedient ones are the punished and the forgiven, just as among the obedient are those who know the matter as it is in reality—these are the workers based on the insight of the People of Unveiling (الكشف) and Existence (الوجود)—and among them are those veiled from that, despite being obedient. Thus, God did not place the people of obedience on a single rank. There is nothing in the spiritual, sensual, or imaginative Existence (الوجود) except the Real (حق), for it exists from the Real, and the Real only brings forth the Real. For this reason,

the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said in his supplication, addressing his Lord, the Exalted: "And all good is in Your hands, and evil is not attributed to You."

For it is the opposite of good. Nothing issues from Good except Good. Evil is merely the non-existence (عدم) of good. Good is entirely Existence (وجود), and evil is entirely non-existence, because it is the manifestation of what has no essence (عين) in reality; it is merely a ruling (حكم), and rulings are relations. We only said 'manifestation' concerning it because that is an Arabic linguistic usage. Imru' al-Qays said: *Law yashrūna maqtali* (If they manifest my killing)—meaning, they make it appear. For that reason, the Exalted said concerning Himself: <<فَإِنَّهُ يَعْلَمُ السِّرَّ>> (Indeed, He knows the secret)—which is the concealment of what has an essence (عين)—<<وأَخْفى‏>> (and what is more hidden)—which is the manifestation of what has no essence, so people imagine that it is real, while God knows that it has no essential existence in the ruling itself. Thus, He knows the secret and what is more hidden, meaning He manifests in the concealment of the secret, just as He said: <<ما بَعُوضَةً فَما فَوْقَها>> (a mosquito or what is above it)—meaning in smallness. Likewise, this is more manifest in concealment than the secret. And the hidden thing is the manifest thing, according to a transmitted linguistic usage. The Exalted said in support of what we mentioned: <<كُلُّ شَيْءٍ هالِكٌ إِلَّا وَجْهَهُ>> (Everything will perish except His Face [وجهه]). Everything that exists, which we witness sensually and know intellectually, is not perishing. Thus, everything is His Face (وجهه), and the face of a thing is its reality (حقيقته). So there is nothing in Existence (الوجود) except God, and there is nothing in Existence except Good, even if the forms are diverse.

For the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, informed us that the Divine Theophany (التجلي الإلهي) varies. And God, the Exalted, informed us that He is <<كُلَّ يَوْمٍ فِي شَأْنٍ>> (every day in a [new] affair). He made it indefinite, and it is nothing but the variation of what He is in. So everything that manifests is none other than Him, and He manifested for Himself. What He witnesses is a single matter, and nothing other than Him multiplies it. For that reason, He said: <<لَهُ الْحُكْمُ وإِلَيْهِ تُرْجَعُونَ>> (To Him belongs the judgment, and to Him you will be returned). That is, whoever believes that everything We made perishes, yet does not know Our intention, when he sees that it does not perish and witnesses the subsistence of its essence (عين) in this world and the Hereafter, he knows what We meant by the perishing thing: that everything not characterized by perishing is My Face (وجهي). Thus, he knows that things are not other than My Face, for they did not perish, and He returned them to their ruling. This is the meaning of His saying: <<وإِلَيْهِ تُرْجَعُونَ>> (and to Him you will be returned), and it is a subtle meaning hidden from one who has not memorized the Quran.

If independence (الغني) is an expression for one whose attribute this is, and independence is an expression for this attribute, then there is no independence except God. Likewise, independence is His attribute. We have only spoken concerning the servant, not concerning the Real (الحق). The servant has absolute need (الفقر المطلق) of his Master, and the Real has absolute independence (الغني المطلق) from the cosmos (العالم). The cosmos has never ceased to be essentially non-existent (مفقود العين), perishing by its essence (هالكا بالذات) in the Presence of its possibility (حضرة إمكانه). Its rulings are what the Real manifests through for Himself, by virtue of what He observes from the reality of the ruling of another possible thing. The cosmos is essentially the extended reality of the existents that appear in the contingent world (الكون), and it is none other than the Real (الحق). So realize, O friend, this Connection (الوصل), for it is a wondrous connection. Its ruling is creation in the Real by the Real, yet there is no creation in the essence of the thing itself, despite the existence of the ruling and the Real's acceptance of the ruling of creation—which is the acceptance of Existence (الوجود) of the ruling of non-existence (العدم). It must be this way. Were it not so, multiplicity (الكثرة) would have no essence (عين). Yet, there is nothing there but multiplicity alongside the Oneness of the Essence (أحدية العين). Thus, the rulings of the many must manifest, and that is none other than the cosmos (العالم), for it is the many, the multiple, while the Real is One in Essence (واحد العين), not multiple. I have cast you upon the Path so that you may know what the matter is, and thus know who you are and who the Real (الحق) is, so that the Lord may be distinguished from the servant. <<وَعَلَى الله قَصْدُ السَّبِيلِ>> (And upon God is the direction of the way).

### The Fifth Connection

from the Treasuries of Generosity (خزائن الجود) concerning what is appropriate to it and related to the Fifth Station (المنزل الخامس). This Fifth Station includes Divine sciences, among them the knowledge of the detailed Divine Return (الرجوع الإلهي) according to the states of the servants to whom He returns. This is a precious knowledge. For God says: <<وإِلَيْهِ يُرْجَعُ الْأَمْرُ كُلُّهُ>> (And to Him all matters are returned), and He says: <<وإِلَيْهِ تُرْجَعُونَ>> (And to Him you will be returned). Here, the return of the Real (الحق) is to the servants from Himself, despite His independence (غناه) from the worlds. When He created them, it was impossible except to return to them, be occupied with them, and preserve the cosmos, for He did not bring it into existence in vain. So He, glorified is He, returns to Him according to what every single person in the cosmos seeks from Him, for He only accepts from him what he is upon in himself regarding his preparedness (الاستعداد). Thus, he rules by his preparedness over the gifts of his Creator, and He only gives him what his request necessitates.

Since the matter is as we mentioned, and the Real (الحق) placed Himself under the request of His servants and obeyed them, He obligated them to obey Him upon the tongues of the Messengers. Whoever among them obeys Him, He manifests to him with the Attribute of the Real (صفة الحق) by which He manifested to the servants in granting what they requested from Him. And whoever disobeys Him, He knows then the reason that led this disobedient one to disobey his Lord. That was nothing but the manifestation of wisdom: the universality of the Divine Return (الرجوع الإلهي) to the servants according to their states, for His Return is universal. So He returned to the obedient with what He promised, and returned to the disobedient with forgiveness, even if He punished. Disobedience appeared in the first human and refusal in the first jinn, and then disobedience spread among humans and jinn according to the commands and prohibitions. That was according to the measure of the Divine Return (الرجوع الإلهي) to them that the Real (الحق) knew through these transgressions. No creature is capable of obeying God, the Exalted, with the obedience of God, according to what the servant requests from Him by his state, whether it displeases him or pleases him. For if the state (الحال) in which the servant stands is evil, the tongue of the state requests from the Real (الحق) what He will recompense him with and return to him, either by choice—and that is only for the state of disobedience present in the disobedient one—or by necessity through designation. Thus, the Divine Return upon the disobedient is either by seizure or by forgiveness, and the Return upon the obedient is by beneficence. The Real (الحق), by His return to the servant, only gives what the servant requested from Him by the tongue of his state (لسان حاله), which is the most eloquent of tongues and the most upright of expressions.

The origin of disobedience in the servants relies upon a Divine relation: that God is the Commander and the Forbidder, the Exalted, and the Will (المشيئة) has the ruling over the true command directed toward the commanded one, either by occurrence or non-occurrence. If the Will is directed toward the occurrence, that servant is called obedient, and that occurrence is called obedience, for the will obeyed the Divine command. But if the Will is not directed toward the occurrence of that command, the will disobeyed the command. The command does not have the power to rule over the Will. So the ruling of the Will (المشيئة) manifested in the commanded servant, and he disobeyed the command or prohibition of his Lord. That is only due to the Divine Will (المشيئة الإلهية). It has become clear to you who the disobedient one is and who the obedient one is, and to what origin the disobedience or obedience of the legally responsible person (المكلف) returns. There is no return except for God upon the servants, and the return of the servants to God is by the return of the Real (الحق) upon them, as the Exalted said: <<ثُمَّ تابَ عَلَيْهِمْ لِيَتُوبُوا>> (Then He turned to them in mercy so that they might turn in repentance). Were it not for God's turning to them, they would not have repented. And *tawba* (repentance) is return (الرجوع). So God returns to the servants more than the servants return to Him, for the servants' return to God is by God's causing them to return. They only returned to God by God.

After God brought the cosmos into existence and maintained Existence (الوجود) upon it, this was only possible through His preservation, for it has no subsistence (بقاء) except through Divine preservation (الحفظ الإلهي). The servant returns to God from himself, and returns to himself from God. The Real (الحق) has no return except to His servants from His servants. He had no return from Himself except the first one, which is expressed as the beginning of the cosmos. If the Will (المشيئة) necessitated choice (الاختيار), we would permit the Real (الحق) to return to Himself. But the Real is not a locus for possibility (الجواز), due to the preference (الترجيح) that possibility requires from a preferrer. Thus, choice in the Will is impossible for God, because possibility is impossible for Him, since it is impossible for God to have a preferrer that prefers one matter over another. He is the Preferrer by His Essence (لذاته). The Will (المشيئة) is unitary in its connection; there is no choice in it. For this reason, the possible (الممكن) is never conceived except with a preferrer.

However, the Real (الحق), by virtue of being Forgiving, sent His veil (ستره) and screen (حجابه) between some of His servants and the impossibility of the Real returning to Himself in His independence from the cosmos, saying in that veil: <<فَإِنَّ الله غَنِيٌّ عَنِ الْعالَمِينَ>> (Indeed, God is independent of the worlds). This ruling can only be established if there is no cosmos, or if the object of the Will is choice. Neither of these two matters occurs while the cosmos exists. The one veiled by this screen says: <<فَإِنَّ الله غَنِيٌّ عَنِ الْعالَمِينَ>> (Indeed, God is independent of the worlds), but he does not know the true nature of the matter. As for the servant from whom this screen is lifted, when he recites it, he knows its object, what the matter is now, what the matter was, and he leaves the object of His independence to the remaining possibilities that have not yet come into existence, for they are infinite in individuals. Thus, there must remain what has not yet been found, and to this, the Divine Attribute of Independence (صفة الغني الإلهي) from the cosmos relates. For a part of the cosmos is called 'cosmos.' Whoever understands Divine Independence (الغني الإلهي) in this way has known it.

As for the purification (تنزيه) of the Real from what His servants purify Him of, apart from Servitude (العبودية), they have no knowledge of what the matter truly is. For he denies his Lord in every state where the Real places Himself with His servants. This is the greatest possible lack of etiquette with God: to purify Him from what He, glorified is He, attributed to Himself by what He attributed to Himself. So he believes in part—which is His saying: <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him)—and disbelieves in part, and <<أُولئِكَ هُمُ الْكافِرُونَ حَقًّا>> (those are the disbelievers in truth). Thus, the servant makes himself more knowledgeable of his Lord than his Lord Himself. There can be no greater ignorance than this. The believing servant should attribute to the Real (الحق) what the Real attributed to Himself, according to the measure that God knows of it, unless he is one whose insight God has unveiled so that he sees the matter as it truly is. This is the hidden polytheism (الشرك الخفي), for it is a subtle contention with God, the Exalted, within the servant, which not everyone perceives, especially the one who falls into it. He imagines himself to be in the attained, while he is in the missed.

For this reason, the Real (الحق), the Exalted, commanded that He be glorified with His praise (بحمده)—meaning, by what He praised Himself with. The Exalted only described Himself with an attribute in the context of praising Himself with that description. But this ignorant purifier (المنزه الجاهل) purifies Him from that description with which the Real described Himself, and proceeds to praise Him with what he sees as praise of God. Yet God only commanded him to purify Him with His praise (بحمده)—meaning, by what He praised Himself with in His Books and upon the tongues of His Messengers. <<وإِنْ من شَيْءٍ إِلَّا يُسَبِّحُ بِحَمْدِهِ>> (There is nothing except that it glorifies Him with His praise), except for this human being, for some of him glorifies Him without His praise, and denies the Real (الحق) in some of what He praised Himself with, without realizing it. For this reason, the Exalted said: <<ولكِنْ لا تَفْقَهُونَ تَسْبِيحَهُمْ إِنَّهُ كانَ حَلِيماً>> (But you do not understand their glorification. Indeed, He is Forbearing). He did not hold you accountable for what you omitted of the praise He bestowed upon Himself, nor did He hasten the punishment upon you, being <<غَفُوراً>> (Forgiving) by concealing the knowledge of that from those who are of this rank.

If the servant desires the salvation of his soul and the attainment of the causes of his happiness, he should only praise God with His praise, whatever it may be, according to God's knowledge of it, without specific designation. If God, the Exalted, takes him upon that, he will become aware of the matter as it truly is, even if he was not among the People of Unveiling (أهل الكشف) in this worldly life. But if he does not do so and offers an interpretation (تأول), he is limited to what he interpreted, and God deprives him of everything that falls outside his interpretation, so he does not see it therein. This is the greatest deprivation. Upon the unveiling of the Hereafter (الكشف الأخروي), he will see the lack of etiquette with God and the ignorance of Him that he was upon, as it is related that the people of this station, when the Real (الحق), the Exalted, manifests to them in the Hereafter, deny Him and do not acknowledge Him, because they only worshipped a Lord restricted by a sign. When He appears to them with that sign, they acknowledge His Lordship (الربوبية), and He is the very thing they denied. What ignorance is greater than acknowledging what one denies? This Station includes the knowledge of those who arrive before God, the knowledge of the types of spiritual openings (الفتوح), and the coming of meanings by the coming of the one in whom they subsist, so the coming is attributed to them, not to Him, and the knowledge of time (الزمان).

### The Sixth Connection

from the Treasuries of Generosity (خزائن الجود) concerning what is appropriate to it and related to the Sixth Station (المنزل السادس).

> Whoever conceals the Real (الحق) and does not disclose Him,
> That person has disbelieved.
> And He is not hidden from one who looks at Him,
> Whether with the eye of the intellect or with sight.
> Blessed is God, who has never ceased
> To manifest in the forms that have appeared.
> For He is their originator perpetually,
> In everything that appears or has appeared.

### [That the worship of God in the Unseen is the essence of His worship in the Visible]

Know, may God support you, that the worship of God in the Unseen (الغيب) is the very essence of His worship in the Visible (الشهادة). For a human being, and every worshipper, cannot rightly worship his object of worship except through witnessing (شهود), either by intellect, by sight, or by insight (بصيرة). The worshipper witnesses Him by insight and thus worships Him. Otherwise, his worship is not valid. He is only worshipped as witnessed, not as absent. If He informs him of His Theophany (تجليه) in forms to the sight, so that he distinguishes Him, he also worships Him based on visual witnessing. This only occurs after he sees Him with the eye of his insight. Whoever combines insight and sight, his worship is perfected outwardly and inwardly. Whoever claims His indwelling (حلوله) in forms is ignorant of both matters. Rather, the Real (الحق) is the very Essence (عين) of the forms, for no container encompasses Him, and no form conceals Him. Ignorance of Him by the ignorant one is what conceals Him. He sees Him but does not know that He is his object of desire.

So the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, said to him: "Worship God as if you see Him."

He commanded him to visualize (الاستحضار), for he knows that one only visualizes what accepts presence. The servant's visualization of his Lord in worship is the very presence of the Worshipped One to him. If he only knows Him within limits and measure, he limits and measures Him. But if he knows Him as purified (منزها) from that, he does not limit or measure Him, even while visualizing Him as if he sees Him. The Gnostic (العارف) does not limit or measure Him because he sees Him as all forms. Whenever he limits Him by one form, another form opposes him, breaking the limit. Thus, the matter is not confined for him due to his inability to encompass the existent and non-existent forms belonging to Him. Therefore, he does not encompass Him in knowledge, as He said: <<ولا يُحِيطُونَ به عِلْماً>> (And they do not encompass Him in knowledge).

Despite His description that He is closer to man than his jugular vein (حبل وريده). The Real (الحق) is closer to him than his own self, for He used the superlative form. The closest proximity is the proximity of the Manifest (الظاهر) to the Hidden (الباطن). Nothing is closer from the Manifest to the Hidden except the Manifest's very Essence (عينه), and nothing is closer from the Hidden to the Manifest except the Hidden's very Essence. And He is <<أَقْرَبُ إِلَيْهِ من حَبْلِ الْوَرِيدِ>> (closer to him than the jugular vein), so He is the very Essence of the one described as having the jugular vein. Thus, we know that He is the Essence (عين) of every form, and since we do not encompass the forms in Existence (الوجود), we do not encompass Him in knowledge. If you say, "Are you then one of the forms?" We say, "We say so too." However, although the forms are the very Essence of the Desired One, they are the rulings of the possible things (الممكنات) within the Essence of the Desired One. We do not care about the ignorance, knowledge, or any description attributed to them, for I know how to attribute, describe, and characterize. <<فَلِلَّهِ الْأَمْرُ من قَبْلُ ومن بَعْدُ>> (To God belongs the command before and after). The Real (الحق) is Real even if you are not, just as the Real is Real even if you are. There is no distinction (فرقان). The Manifest (الظاهر) has a ruling that the Hidden (الباطن) does not have, in the sense that you called it Hidden in worship. And the Hidden has a ruling that the Manifest does not have, in the sense that you called it Manifest in worship. Every ruling has a known station (مقام), and every station has a known ruling. Nothing is known except by Him, and nothing is worshipped except by Him. For this reason, the Real (الحق) alerted those who lack knowledge of what we mentioned to the rank of the knowers of God (العلماء بالله), saying that He is the hearing and sight of the servant. You only saw Him by Him, and you only heard Him by Him. Thus, His Essence (عينه) is the Essence of your hearing and your sight. You only worshipped Him by Him. After the declaration of the Real, mighty is His Name and majestic is His mention, there is no further declaration, and after His rulings concerning what He has ruled, there are no further rulings.

> He is none other than His Essence (عينه) by report,
> Yet He is none other than other-than-Him by sight.
> Where are the people of contemplation concerning His Essence (ذاته)?
> They have embarked upon a great danger therein.
> The matter conflicted for them, so they have
> No knowledge of Him by the ruling of contemplation.
> If it is said, "He is it," it is said to them, "He is not it,"
> Because He is your object of desire through thought.
> Or if it is said, "What is He?" it is said, "He is it,"
> For He is the very Essence (عين) of what you witness in the forms.

I saw a spring (عين) of fresh milk, the like of which I had never seen in whiteness and goodness in its substance. I entered it until it reached my chest, and it was flowing. I was astonished by that and heard strange Divine speech saying: "Whoever prostrates to other than God by the command of God, seeking nearness to God, in obedience to God, has attained happiness and salvation. And whoever prostrates to other than God without the command of God, seeking nearness to God, has become wretched." For God, mighty and majestic is He, says: <<وأَنَّ الْمَساجِدَ لِلَّهِ فَلا تَدْعُوا مَعَ الله أَحَداً>> (And that the mosques are for God, so do not invoke anyone alongside God). For God is with the creation, but the creation is not with God, because He knows them. <<هُوَ مَعَهُمْ أَيْنَ ما كانُوا>> (He is with them wherever they are), in the capacity of their places, times, and states. The creation is not with Him, exalted is His Majesty, for the creation does not know Him until it is with Him. So, whoever invokes God *with* the creation is not like one who invokes the creation *with* God. <<فَلا تَدْعُوا مَعَ الله أَحَداً>> (So do not invoke anyone alongside God). Prostration to other than God is only valid because God is with the creation wherever they are. We do not know Him or find Him except through the creation. Prostration, in reality, is for God, who is described by companionship (المعية) with the creation. For this reason, the direction of prayer (القبلة) was legislated, as the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, God is in the direction of the worshipper's prayer." The *Qibla* is not God, yet God is in it. So we were commanded to prostrate to it because God is in it and with it.

Whoever sees the creation with his sight has seen the Real (الحق) with his insight absolutely. When he sees that, he is not permitted to prostrate to it unless He commands him to prostrate. Even if it is for God, it never occurs in the senses except to other than God, because it is not valid for prostration to occur *to* God, since God encompasses everything. All directions are equal in their relation, or the relation of the Real to them is equal. Whoever falls backward has not prostrated to God, even though God is behind him just as He is in front of him. But God only regarded his face; He did not regard any of the servant's directions except his face. Therefore, prostration to other than God is not valid except by God's command. God, the Exalted, said: <<اسْجُدُوا لِآدَمَ>> (Prostrate to Adam). So the prostration was to other than God, but worship (العبادة) is for God and is never for other than God, for there is nothing greater than polytheism (الشرك). The polytheist (المشرك) said: <<ما نَعْبُدُهُمْ إِلَّا لِيُقَرِّبُونا إِلَى الله زُلْفى‏>> (We only worship them that they may bring us nearer to God in proximity). They did not worship the partners for their essences (أعيانهم), so they were only held accountable for worshipping them. God does not command His creation, nor is it valid for Him to command His creation to worship a creature. But it is permissible for Him to command us to prostrate to a creature.

Whoever prostrates in worship (عبادة) to a creature, whether by God's command or without God's command, has become wretched. But whoever prostrates to a creature without worshipping it, if it was by God's command, it was obedience, and he attained happiness. If he prostrated to a creature without worshipping it, without God's command, it was a monasticism (رهبانية) he innovated, and he did not observe it <<حَقَّ رِعايَتِها ... إِلَّا ابْتِغاءَ رِضْوانِ الله>> (as it should be observed... except seeking God's pleasure), because he only intended it as a means of nearness to God. This state was not devoid of God. God is according to the servant's expectation of Him; He does not disappoint him. So let him expect good of Him. The polytheists must be seized for transgressing by placing the Name in an improper place and context, and no command concerning that came to him from God. It is impossible for worship (عبادة) to be rejected, even if prostration is rejected. Were it not for placing the Name of Divinity (الألوهية) upon the partner, they would not have worshipped it, for the souls of humans naturally disdain the worship of creatures, especially those like themselves. So they applied the Divine Name to them so that none other than God would be worshipped by them; no creature would be worshipped by them. The polytheist only associated partners with God by placing this Name upon the creature out of purification (التنزيه) for God, the Great, the Exalted. This is because the polytheist necessarily requires outward movements in his worship that demand restriction, and he necessarily requires an imaginative conception (تصور خيالي) because he possesses imagination (خيال), and he necessarily requires knowledge based on an intellectual proof that necessitates the purification (تنزيه) of the Real (الحق) from restriction and the negation of likeness. For this reason, they transferred the Name to the partner.

And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to Gabriel, peace be upon him, in the context of teaching God's servants: "Worship God as if you see Him."

Thus, He commanded him to conceive Him in the Imagination (الخيال) as visible. God did not forbid His servants from purifying Him (تنزيهه) or imagining Him (تخيله); rather, He forbade Him from being sensually perceived by him, knowing that it is the nature of Imagination to embody and form what is neither a body nor a form. For the Imagination (الخيال) only perceives Him thus; it is an inner sense, restricted, between the intelligible and the sensible—I mean the Imagination. The Real (الحق) only established all of this due to the Mercy that <<وَسِعَتْ كُلَّ شَيْءٍ>> (encompasses all things), so that when He shows mercy to those who were seized, the creation knows that this Divine Mercy was previously announced by the Real in the worldly abode, the abode of obligation, so the knowers do not deny it. God only brought the cosmos out of non-existence (العدم), which is evil, for the sake of the good He intended for it, which is nothing but Existence (الوجود). Thus, it exists essentially toward happiness, and its affair ends there by ruling. The abode in which polytheism occurred is an abode of mixture; it is the abode of ambiguity (شبهة), which is the world. It has an aspect toward the Real (الحق) by virtue of its existence, and an aspect toward other than the Real by virtue of what is annihilated within it and transferred from it to the Hereafter. Ambiguity (الشبهة) is the equal attribution of lawfulness and unlawfulness to it. God only made it of this description in order to establish an excuse for the servants when He intends to show them universal mercy. How gentle God is with His creation! For the Maker has concern for His making. The knowing believer does not deny that the polytheist worshipped God, for he heard him say: <<ما نَعْبُدُهُمْ إِلَّا لِيُقَرِّبُونا إِلَى الله زُلْفى‏>> (We only worship them that they may bring us nearer to God in proximity). The polytheist did not deny God, the Exalted; rather, he affirmed Him and affirmed for Him greatness and majesty over the one he took as a means of nearness to Him. If you know from where the one who was seized was seized, and that the seizure in the Hereafter, like the prescribed penalties (الحدود) in this world, does not affect the belief in God's Existence (وجود الله) nor the Oneness of His Greatness (أحدية العظمة) which surpasses all greatness in the view of everyone. It is from God's mercy that He made whoever <<يُعَظِّمْ شَعائِرَ الله>> (magnifies the symbols of God) and the sacred things of God—and the symbols are the signs and rites—a means of nearness to God, and that this is <<مِنْ تَقْوَى الْقُلُوبِ>> (from the piety of the hearts). This, too, is a participation in greatness, and it is legislated for us. The polytheist only magnified the partner due to the greatness of God, when he saw that greatness flows through creatures, which every human finds in his nature. Despite this, the polytheist singled out the greatest greatness of God in his heart for God. The accountability only occurred because what happened was without God's command concerning specific individuals, and the Name was transferred to those individuals.

### Connection

As for the fundamental principles (الأصول), they are preserved by the primordial nature (الفطرة).

upon which Allah created the creatures. Do you not see what some of them said: <<And nothing destroys us except Time (al-Dahr)>>?

So Allah the Exalted said in the clear and sound Revelation: "Do not curse Time (al-Dahr), for Allah is Time (al-Dahr)." You see it.

Did He say this and bring it forth in vain? No, by Allah! Rather, He brought it forth as a mercy to His servants. For Time (al-Dahr), according to those who speak of it, is not something sensible to them. Rather, it is an imagined matter whose form in the cosmos is the existence of night and day resulting from the movement of the star of the sun in its sphere, which is moved by the movement of the Greatest Sphere (al-Falak al-A'zam), the sphere of the constellations (falak al-Buruj), which has the day through its movement, just as night and day exist through the appearance of the star of the sun within it. The day existed, yet there was neither night nor day, along with the existence of degrees (darajat) and minutes (daqa'iq) and less than that. Thus, with this, neither general polytheism (shirk 'amm) nor general negation (ta'til 'amm) is valid. Rather, these are names they coined and applied to sensible and imagined entities ('ayan) without the command of Allah. They proceeded without Divine instruction (tawqif). We have found the matter to be exactly what they found, but without command. Therefore, verify this connection (wasl), for it is extremely subtle. End of the Twenty-Fifth Journey (Safar) with the conclusion of the Sixth Connection (Wasl) of Chapter 369.

In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful.

### "The Seventh Connection" from the Keys to the Treasuries of Generosity (Jūd)

From Chapter 369. This treasury contains the necessity for the servant ('abd) to remain behind the rank (rutba) of his Lord (Sayyid) and to purify his servitude ('ubudiyya) to Allah from all others, just as he affirmed this in the grasp of the progeny (qabdat al-dhurriyya). The Real (al-Haqq) desires that this affirmation accompany him throughout his worldly life, the place of veiling (hijab) and concealment (satr). For the Real (al-Haqq) has precedence over Creation (al-Khalq) in Existence (al-Wujud) in all respects, and in station (makana) and rank (rutba). He was, and there was no creature. This is the precedence of Existence (taqaddum al-Wujud). He decreed, judged, commanded, and executed an execution that cannot be revoked or judged against. This is the precedence of Rank (taqaddum al-Rutba). So, <<And you do not will except that Allah wills that you will>>. Thus, it is necessary to remain behind the rank of the Real (al-Haqq) in all respects.

For the servant was given Multiplicity (al-Kathra) so that Oneness (al-Ahadiyya) belongs to Him, the Exalted. And every creature was given the oneness of distinction (ahadiyyat al-tamyiz) so that Oneness (al-Ahadiyya) might be a direct experience (dhawqan) for him, enabling him to know that there is a oneness, from which he may know the Divine Oneness (al-Ahadiyya al-Ilahiyya), until he witnesses it for Allah the Exalted. For if a creature did not possess a oneness of direct experience (dhawqan) by which it is distinguished from all others, it would not know that Allah possesses a Oneness (Ahadiyya) by which He is distinguished from His creation. Thus, it is indispensable. Multiplicity (al-Kathra) has the oneness of multiplicity, and every number has a oneness that does not belong to another number, such as two and three, and so on, up to what is intellectually infinite in existence. Thus, every multiplicity among these has a specific oneness.

In any case, the Real (al-Haqq) has made it incumbent upon His servant to remain behind the rank of his Creator, just as He, Glory be to Him, delayed our knowledge ('ilm) of Him after our knowledge of ourselves. Thus, the existence of the originated knowledge concerning Him is posterior in existence to the existence of the originated knowledge concerning ourselves. He established preference (mufadala) in the World ('Alam), one part over another, so that we might know preference through direct experience (dhawqan) from our own souls (nufus), and thereby know the distinction (fasl) of the Real (al-Haqq) over us, even though our knowledge of Him is posterior to our knowledge of ourselves. This is so that we may know that our knowledge of ourselves was only meant to indicate our knowledge of Him. Thus, we know that we are sought for Him, not for ourselves or our essences ('ayan), because the indicator (dalil) is sought for the indicated (madlul), not for itself. For this reason, the indicator and the indicated never coincide. Therefore, Creation (al-Khalq) and the Real (al-Haqq) never coincide in any respect.

The servant ('abd) is a servant for himself, and the Lord (Rabb) is a Lord for Himself. Servitude ('ubudiyya) is only valid for one who knows it and thus knows that there is nothing of Lordship (Rububiyya) in it. And Lordship (Rububiyya) is only valid for one who knows it and thus knows that there is nothing of servitude ('ubudiyya) in it. Therefore, He made it incumbent upon His servants to remain behind His Lordship (Rububiyya). He legislated the Prayer (Salat) for him so that He might name him 'the one who prays' (al-musalli), who is the one who remains behind the rank of his Lord. He attributed the Prayer to Himself, the Exalted, so that it might be known that the matter necessitates the posteriority of the originated knowledge concerning Him to the originated knowledge concerning the creature. Thus, He said: <<He it is Who prays upon you (yusalli 'alaykum), and His angels>>. And He said: <<So pray to your Lord (fasalli li-Rabbika)>>.

Since we know that whoever remains behind a matter is cut off from it, we know that each one is undoubtedly distinguished from the other in his rank (rutba). Even if what is applied to one is applied to the other, a partnership (ishtirak) is imagined, yet there is no partnership in reality, for the rank has distinguished him. Thus, each one accepts that application according to what the rank by which he is distinguished dictates. For we know with certainty that the Divine Names (al-Asma' al-Ilahiyya) that we possess are applied to Allah and are applied to us. And we know with certainty, through our knowledge of our rank and our knowledge of the rank of the Real (al-Haqq), that the attribution of those Names—in which there is apparent linguistic partnership—to Allah is different from their attribution to us. He was separated from us only by His Lordship (Rububiyya), and we were separated from Him only by our servitude ('ubudiyya). Whoever among us adheres to his rank has not wronged himself; rather, he has given the matter its due.

> The Real (al-Haqq) has become manifest to you,
> And Creation (al-Khalq) has become manifest to you.
> So say what you will, or name it,
> For all of His saying is the Real (Haqq).
> There is no falsehood (mayn) in His being,
> And there is no truth (sidq) in our being.

In this meaning is the saying of Labid: "Behold, everything besides Allah is vain (batil)." The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said concerning this verse: "The truest verse spoken by the Arabs is the saying of Labid," meaning this half of it.

We say: This is a rank (rutba) with which Allah has not singled out anyone among mankind and praised him for it, except the one who remembers (al-dhakir). This is because the one who remembers is he who had knowledge of a matter, then forgot it due to the forgetfulness upon which man was created, as Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, said: <<They forgot Allah, so He forgot them>>. The form of their forgetting is that they imagined, due to the deeds, wealth, and ownership that Allah attributed to them, that they had a share in Lordship (Rububiyya), or that Allah had given them a portion of it through His saying: <<or what your right hands possess>>.

When Allah the Exalted cared for those He cared for among them and granted them mercy from Himself, he remembered the Name of his Lord. And Allah says: "I am the companion of him who remembers Me." The rememberers (al-dhakirun) are the companions of the Real (al-Haqq). Remembrance (Dhikr) bequeathed him the companionship of the Real, and companionship bequeathed him the witnessing (mushahada) of the Real and seeing Him in things. The Veracious One (al-Siddiq) says: "I did not see a thing except that I saw Allah before it," and 'Umar [said]: "with it," and another: "after it," and another: "in it," and another: "I did not see a thing without a connection to something."

And the vision of the Real (ru'yat al-Haqq) bequeathed him his remaining behind what he had imagined: that Allah the Exalted had given him a share in Lordship (Rububiyya), that it was among his descriptions, and that he had a footing in it in some respect. So he remained behind that through Remembrance (Dhikr). Thus, He said: <<And he remembered the Name of his Lord, and prayed (fa-salla)>>—meaning, he retreated to the station of his servitude ('ubudiyya) and singled out Lordship (Rububiyya) for Allah the Exalted. Thus, he succeeded in all his aspects. This attribute is not witnessed by anyone other than the rememberer (al-dhakir). The rememberer is a servant ('abd) purified for Allah the Exalted.

Do you not see what He said concerning the one who was characterized by the opposite of this state, when the remembrance of his Lord—which is the Qur'an—came to him, reminding him of himself and his Lord: <<He neither believed (saddaqa) [the one who brought it] that it was from his Lord, nor did he pray (salla)>>? He means: nor did he retreat from his claim and his arrogance, even though he heard the true saying of Allah. Even if it were not from Allah, it is incumbent upon the intelligent person, when he hears the Real (al-Haqq) from whomever he hears it, to return to it and affirm it, so that he may be among its people. Whoever rejects the Real (al-Haqq) has not believed that saying in what it indicates, regardless of who said it.
