So Allah condemned him and said—but this is a clarification for the completion of the story—<<He denied the one who brought it to him>>, who is the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, and he denied the Real (al-Haqq), either through ignorance, not knowing that it was the Real, or through obstinacy, being certain that it was the Real in reality, but deceiving himself because this Messenger brought it, as He said concerning one whose attribute is this: <<And they rejected them, while their souls were convinced of them, out of injustice and arrogance>>.

Then He said: <<And he turned away after denying the Real (al-Haqq) and the one who brought it. So he turned away from the Real. Then he went to his family swaggering (yatamatta)>>. This is the occupation of the arrogant person, whose mind is preoccupied, thinking, and confused, whom what he heard has made lazy. For, outwardly, he knows it is the Real (al-Haqq), because Allah only brings the miracle (mu'jiza) to those whom He knows have the capacity to accept it, due to what Allah has instilled in them of that capacity. For this reason, the signs (dalalat) differed from every prophet and for every group. If He had brought them a sign that they were unable to accept due to their ignorance, Allah would not have held them accountable for their turning away or their rejection of it, for Allah is All-Knowing, Wise, and Just.

Whoever retreats from the right of another to what he deserves in himself has been fair to himself, and the claimant of a right against him has no demand to make. Thus, he has attained goodness with both hands. Allah has made him aware of the comprehensive principles of all goodness, for <<whoever is given wisdom has certainly been given abundant goodness>>. The Wise One (al-Hakim) is he who places everything in its rank (rutba) and gives every possessor of a right his due. He possesses the conclusive argument (al-hujjat al-baligha) and the crushing word. His witnessing (mushahada) is never interrupted, and the Divine Aid (al-Ma'una al-Ilahiyya) in his servitude ('ibada) is never delayed from assisting him.

For we have assumed him to be the servant ('abd) of the Lord (Sayyid), not a possession (milk). A possession may be among those who understand their servitude and those who do not. The state of the servant is hearing and obedience to his Lord. Everything other than the servant is a possession (milk) in which the Owner disposes as He wills, without any praise being attached to it that would negate His right to dispose of it. This is unlike the one who understands, who is the servant. If he stands in the disposition of the Real (al-Haqq) in the position of possessions (amwal), Allah praises him for that, because Allah has singled him out in his origination (nash'a) with the power to prevent and reject the word of the Real (kalimat al-Haqq), and enabled him to obey and disobey. So, when he utilized that, praise was bestowed upon him, just as Allah praised the angels with His saying: <<They do not disobey Allah in what He commands them, and they do what they are commanded>>. If there were nothing in their power and origination that necessitated rejecting the command of Allah and nothing that necessitated accepting it, Allah would not have praised them as He did by negating disobedience from them and affirming their performance of what He commanded them, for the compelled one (al-majbur) receives no praise.

Do you not see the one who prays (al-musalli) when he stands before his Lord in prayer, folding his arms (yatakattaf)? This is the occupation of the humble servant before his Lord during his intimate conversation (munajat). The Sunna has been transmitted regarding this, and it is better than letting the hands hang down. This is because when Allah the Exalted divided the Prayer (Salat) between Himself and His servant into two halves, one part is purely for Him, the Exalted, from the beginning of the Fatiha up to His saying: <<the Day of Judgment (Yawm al-Din)>>. This is in the position of the servant's right hand, because <<All power belongs to Allah>>. So we gave Him the right. The other part is purely for the servant, from His saying: <<Guide us (Ihdina)>> to the end of the Surah. This part is in the position of the left hand, which is the weaker side, and this is the rank of the servant, for he was created from weakness initially and returned to weakness finally.

And one part is between Allah and His servant. This part combines Allah and His servant, which is His saying: <<You alone we worship (Iyyaka na'budu) and You alone we ask for help (Iyyaka nasta'in)>>. Because of this combination, the servant joins his hands in prayer when he stands. Thus, the servant's prayer is perfected by joining his hands. The form of this folding is to place the right hand over the left, as we established that the right belongs to Allah, so it has superiority over the left. The form is to place the palm of the right hand over the back of the left hand, the wrist, and the forearm, so as to encompass the entire hand which Allah commanded His servant to purify during ablution for prayer. Thus, he takes the wrist and what is adjacent to it from the palm and forearm. Look at how clear this wisdom is for one who has eyes.

Then the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade the one praying (al-musalli) from raising his eyes to the sky during his prayer, for Allah is in the direction of the servant's Qibla. Nothing confronts him in his standing except the horizon, which is his Qibla that he faces. It is commendable for him to look at the place of his prostration (sujud), for it is what alerts him to the Gnosis (ma'rifa) of himself and his servitude ('ubudiyya). For this reason, Allah made proximity (qurba) in prayer occur during the state of prostration. Man is not protected from Satan in any part of his prayer except during prostration. When he prostrates, Satan withdraws from him, weeping over himself and saying: "The son of Adam was commanded to prostrate, and he prostrated, so he has Paradise. I was commanded to prostrate, and I refused, so I have the Fire."

### "The Eighth Connection" from the Treasuries of Generosity (Jūd)

This is related to the connection we just finished, which is that the servant ('abd) is posterior in reality (fi nafs al-amr) to the rank (rutba) of his Creator. He is prevented from witnessing (shuhud) this by the forgetfulness (nisyan), inadvertence (sahw), and heedlessness (ghafla) that Allah placed in him. Thus, he imagines that he has a footing in mastery (siyada), while the state (hal) testifies to the contrary. Therefore, by his state, he is a verifier (muhaqqiq), but in reality (fi nafs al-amr), he is like the possessor of witnessing (shuhud). He has no felicity (sa'ada) in this, but rather wretchedness (shaqa'), and this is the ultimate deprivation (hirman). He remains thus until the veil (ghita') is lifted, and his sight sharpens, and he sees the matter as it truly is, and he believes in it. But his belief does not benefit him, for faith (iman) is only through report (khabar), not through direct sight ('iyan). The believer (mu'min) is only he who believes in the Unseen (al-Ghayb), which is the report that came from Allah. For a report, as a report, accepts truth and falsehood, just as the contingent (al-mumkin) accepts Existence (al-Wujud) and non-existence.

Know that no one is afflicted except through heedlessness (ghafla) regarding the rights (huquq) that the Law (Shar') has made incumbent upon him to fulfill. Whoever keeps these rights before his eyes and strives his utmost to fulfill them, and then obstacles (mawāni') intervene between him and their fulfillment, which establish an excuse for him before Allah, has given the matter its due, and Allah has fulfilled His covenant. There is no blame or fault upon him, nor does the Real (al-Haqq) address him with the necessity of a right upon him alongside that obstacle.

Obstacles (mawāni') are of two types: one type occurs with presence (hudur), and one type occurs with absence of presence, which is heedlessness (ghafla). As for the type that occurs with presence, it is divided into two sections. One section relates to examining whether that obligation is incumbent upon him or not. He exerts the utmost effort he is commanded by Allah to seek the evidence (dalil) for the obligation of that matter, but he does not find it. If he is one of the people of independent legal reasoning (Ahl al-Ijtihad), nothing is incumbent upon him except what his evidence dictates. Although it is obligatory in reality (fi nafs al-amr) according to Allah, this mujtahid has erred, yet he is rewarded by Allah according to the text of Allah and the text of His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him. Allah only commanded him with that, and he has fulfilled what Allah commanded him: the exertion of effort (ijtihad) in seeking the evidence, which he did not find.

It is not permissible for the mujtahid to imitate (yuqallid) another in a ruling whose evidence he does not know. However, part of his ijtihad, if he does not find evidence, is to ask the people of ijtihad who ruled it obligatory about that matter. The form of his question is to say to them: "What is your evidence for what you have made obligatory in this matter?" He does not imitate them in the ruling. If they inform him of their evidence, and if that evidence is something he already encountered in his ijtihad and invalidated, then he is not obliged to consider it or rule by it, for he has already left it behind. If, however, he did not encounter it in his previous examination, then he must examine the evidence of the mujtahid he questioned: Is it evidence in the view of this questioning mujtahid, or is it not? If his ijtihad leads him to conclude that it is evidence, just as it is for the one who adopted it as evidence, then he is obliged to act upon it. If he invalidates it in a way that the other person did not encounter, then he is not permitted to adopt it and imitate the one questioned in the ruling that this evidence dictated to that mujtahid. This is one obstacle.

The other section is that he knows the obligation upon him, whether it is an action or an omission, but then something intervenes between him and it: if it is an omission, it is necessity (idhtirar); if it is an action, it is lack of ability (adam istita'a). There is no other obstacle besides this, provided there is presence (hudur).

The other type of obstacle is heedlessness (ghafla), which is of two kinds: heedlessness *concerning* something (ghafla 'an kadha) and heedlessness *within* something (ghafla fi kadha). Heedlessness *concerning* something is abandoning it entirely. He is not held accountable for this before Allah, for Allah, out of mercy for His servants, has lifted accountability for error (khata')—which is the state of the mujtahid we mentioned earlier—and forgetfulness (nisyan), which is heedlessness, and what their souls whisper (hadathat bihi anfusuhum), unless they act upon it or speak it. Speech is an action, so one is held accountable for it insofar as it is uttered. If the utterance itself is the only action, such as backbiting (ghiba) and slander (namima), then one is held accountable for it according to what that utterance leads to. If he uttered it, and it has an action beyond the utterance, but he did not perform the action, then he is only accountable for the utterance itself. He is responsible before Allah regarding his tongue. Worrying (al-hamm) about something does not fall under the category of whispering of the soul (hadith al-nafs), for worrying about something has a different ruling in the Law (Shar') than the whispering of the soul. This is because it has specific contexts. For whoever intends <<deviation (ilhad) with injustice (zulm) in the Sacred Mosque of Mecca, We will make him taste a painful punishment>>, whether or not the injustice he intended occurred. As for outside the Sacred Mosque of Mecca, he is not held accountable for the worry (hamm). If he does not perform what he worried about, a good deed is written for him, provided he abandoned it specifically for the sake of Allah. If he did not abandon it for the sake of Allah, nothing is written for him, neither for nor against him. This is the difference between the whispering of the soul and the intention (irada), which is worry. This and its like are a mercy from Allah to His servants.

As for heedlessness *within* something (ghafla fi kadha), it would be a difficult obligation if man were commanded with it. However, Allah does not hold His servants accountable for heedlessness *within* something, just as He does not hold them accountable for heedlessness *concerning* something. For when one is heedless *within* something, he is heedless concerning a part of the parts of what he is legislating or performing, so it is a form of heedlessness *concerning* something. Allah has legislated a ruling for heedlessness *within* something in certain actions, such as the one who is inadvertent (sahi) in his prayer. Prostration of Inadvertence (sujud al-sahw) has been legislated for him to mend what he was inadvertent about and to spite Satan who whispered to him until inadvertence and heedlessness occurred in what he was performing. But if he *pretends* to be heedless (taghaful) until that pretense causes him heedlessness, Allah holds him accountable for it, for he is deliberately intending what intervenes between him and what Allah has made incumbent upon him to do or omit.

When a person is heedless or inadvertent concerning his servitude ('ubudiyya) and sees a superiority (fadl) for himself over another servant like him—especially if the other servant is his possession (milk yamin), or if this heedless person is one of the people of authority (uli al-amr), such as a Sultan or Governor—he sees a distinction (maziyya) for himself over others, but he does not see that distinction as belonging to the rank (rutba) in which he was placed, if he is one of the people of authority, nor to the attribute (sifa) inherent in him by way of Divine specialization, such as knowledge ('ilm) or noble character. Thus, he does not distinguish between himself and the rank, nor between the attribute and the one described by it. Such a person is characterized by ruinous ignorance and heedlessness. For this reason, in this state, he says: "You are like me," or "So-and-so is like me," or "He is my equal." And "Who is So-and-so? What is the value of So-and-so? Is he not just my servant, or one of my subjects?" or similar derogatory statements, which he purifies himself from and attaches to the other person. This is contrary to the one who is not heedless of himself, for he attributes the superiority (fadl) to the attribute and the rank, not to himself, for he did not attain it by merit, but rather by Divine favor (imtina'), either for his wretchedness (shaqawa) if he denies it, or for his felicity (sa'ada) if he thanks it.

Were it not for the rule of ignorance in one whose attribute is this, he would not be characterized by it. If he knows all this and yet *pretends* to be heedless (taghaful), then he is an arrogant denier (mubahit). This is a greater injustice. In this state, he is like the one who takes a false oath (al-yamin al-ghamūs), while the heedless one (al-ghafil) is like the one who takes a vain oath (laghw al-yamin). If he is mindful of his reality, knowing that what he possesses, which others are deprived of, may be stripped from him and bestowed upon that other person whom he despised due to Allah's neglect of him, then he thanks Allah for His favor, prays to Allah that the other person may attain what Allah gave him, and compassion (shafaqa) overtakes him. For even if the other is an unbeliever (kafir), he is his brother in that they both originate from a single soul (nafs wahida). If he is a believer (mu'min), he is his brother through the brotherhood of specific religious felicity.

### [Compassion for Allah's Creation and Mercy for Allah's Servants]

In any case, compassion (shafaqa) for Allah's Creation (Khalq) and mercy (rahma) for Allah's servants ('ibad) are incumbent upon him.

The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Help your brother, whether he is an oppressor (zalim) or oppressed (mazlum)." As for helping the oppressed, it is known to all. As for helping the oppressor, it is a subtle prophetic mercy (rahma nabawiyya khafiyya). For he knew that oppression (zulm) is not among the inherent characteristics (shiyam) of souls (nufus), because they are essentially pure in Essence (tahirat al-Dhat bi-al-asala). Everything that diminishes their purity is an accidental matter ('aradī) that occurred to them due to the receptivity inherent in their nature (jibilla). What is among their inherent characteristics is domination (qahr) and manifestation (zuhur).

It is from here that Iblis entered upon them with his whispering (waswasa). Ignorant indeed was the poet who said:

> Oppression is among the inherent characteristics of souls,
> So if you find a chaste one, it is due to a cause that he does not oppress.

He was neither fair nor did he speak the truth. If he had said, instead of oppression, that domination (qahr) is among the inherent characteristics of souls [it would be true].

The oppression (zulm) that issues from Zayd against anyone is not from him; rather, it is from the one who casts it upon him, which is Satan. Man finds a defense against it within himself, because that is not among the inherent characteristics of souls. What is characteristic of them is only the acquisition of benefits (jalb al-manafi') and the repulsion of harms (daf' al-madarr). In repelling harms, the human soul shares with all animals. The acquisition of benefits is what the human soul (al-nafs al-insaniyya) is specialized in. If you see an animal acquiring benefits, it is only for the sake of repelling harms, not for any other reason. Every harm that arises from an animal against another animal or against a human is only for the sake of repelling harm from itself specifically.

Since the human soul is of this nature, and oppression occurs from him against someone, he is called an oppressor (zalim). Helping the oppressor is to help him against Iblis, who whispers in his breast with the oppression that occurs from him, using speech that souls find sweet and submit to. Thus, you assist him in repelling what Satan whispered to him. This is his help when he is an oppressor. For this reason, the tradition (khabar) regarding helping the oppressor states that one should restrain his hand (ya'khudh 'ala yadihi), and what is meant by this is what we have mentioned. This is why the term 'help' (nusra) was used, which brotherhood necessitates, because help must be directed against something, and there is nothing there except what we mentioned.

Because the enemy who whispers in his breast swears by his Lord: <<I will surely mislead them all, except Your servants among them, the purified ones (al-mukhlasin)>>. These are the ones whom Allah has purified for Himself from what was cast upon them, and in whom is the light of preservation (hifz) and infallibility ('isma). For this reason, the Exalted said: <<Indeed, My servants—you have no authority (sultan) over them>>—meaning, no power, domination, or argument (hujja)—because Allah has taken charge of their preservation and instruction through the piety (taqwa) He placed in them. When they took Allah, Glorious is His Majesty, as a shield, the accursed one found no way to enter upon them with anything. Wherever he turned to enter upon him with something that would remove him from his religion and knowledge, he found the Face of Allah (Wajh Allah) in that direction protecting him. Thus, he cannot reach him through whispering (waswasa).

So, he embodies himself for him in the form of a human like him, and the person imagines he is a human. He comes to him with temptation (ighwa') through his ear, entering upon him regarding what is forbidden by means of an interpretation (ta'wil), the least of which is that it permits the action for him. Thus, falling into it does not harm him because of that interpretation, due to the knowledge that man does not initially commit disobedience to Allah without the whispering of the enemy who beautifies his evil deed so that he sees it as good.

When he comes in this manner to the scholar ('alim) over whom he has no authority (sultan)—by means of the interpretation we mentioned regarding what he wants to make him fall into—that scholar becomes one of the people of ijtihad. If he errs, he has one reward; if he is correct, he has two rewards. So he is rewarded in every case, and the enemy's desire is not fulfilled. Even if he forgets, as Adam forgot, Allah the Exalted, Who legislated disobedience and obedience and clarified their rulings, lifted the ruling of accountability for disobedience regarding the forgetful and the mistaken, just as He lifted it regarding the mujtahid. Man only moves within a legislated matter.

The Face of Allah (Wajh Allah) has encompassed man outwardly and inwardly. Wherever Satan turns to him, outwardly or inwardly, the Face of Allah is there protecting him. Thus, he has no authority (sultan) over him. This is related to the Prophet's saying, peace and blessings be upon him, concerning his companion (qarin): "Allah helped me against him, so he submitted (aslama)," with the *mīm* raised (damma) indicating a statement of fact. Thus, he has no authority over him—meaning, no argument (hujja)—because the argument here is legal (shar'iyya). Even if the enemy casts something upon his outward or inward self, and the Law (Shar') contains a ruling lifting accountability for what this enemy brought, then he has no authority over him, because the legal argument belongs to him. <<For Allah is the conclusive argument (al-hujjat al-baligha)>>. And his saying, "Allah helped me against him," is Allah's help to him with the argument, so he does not care.

For this reason, He legislated for His servants to say: <<And You alone we ask for help (Iyyaka nasta'in)>>—meaning, through You we seek victory. And there is nothing there but Knowledge ('Ilm). It is a victorious report (khabar nasir) that Allah gives His servant. What Adam forgot was the Exalted's saying to him: <<Indeed, this is an enemy to you and to your spouse>>. So he forgot what Allah informed him of regarding his enmity, and he accepted his advice.

When Iblis knew that Adam was protected by Allah, and saw that Allah had forbidden him from *approaching* the tree, not *approaching* the fruit, he came in the form of eating, not in the form of approaching. For he knew that Adam would not approach due to his Lord's prohibition against approaching the tree. So he brought him its fruit. Adam and his wife Eve ate, and they believed Iblis, the liar, in his saying: <<Shall I guide you to the Tree of Immortality (Shajarat al-Khuld) and a kingdom that will not decay?>> And so it was: that eating bequeathed him immortality in Paradise and the kingdom that does not decay. He did not tell him *when*. He made that a specific property of that tree for whoever ate from it. This bequeathed him Divine Selection (al-Ijtiba' al-Ilahi). So Allah sent him down for vicegerency (khilafa) on Earth, confirming what He had said to the angels: <<Indeed, I am placing upon the earth a vicegerent (khalifa)>>. He sent Eve down for procreation, and He sent Iblis down for temptation (ighwa') so that all that he tempts the children of Adam with would revert back to him when Allah's mercy encompasses mankind.

Allah made every transgression that occurs from man to be from the casting and temptation of the enemy. Thus, He said: <<Satan promises you poverty and commands you to immorality (fahsha')>>—meaning, to its manifestation, intending by that its occurrence from you. This is because He knew that the Real (al-Haqq) has lifted accountability from man for what he whispers to himself and what evil he worries about, unless he manifests it upon his limbs through action, which is immorality (fahsha'). Then the Exalted said: <<But Allah promises you forgiveness from Him>> for the immorality that Satan commanded you with, <<and bounty>> for the poverty he promised you. This is the greatest and most severe verse that passed over Iblis's hearing, for he knew that his temptation would not benefit him. For this reason, he strives only for polytheism (shirk) specifically, because he heard the Real (al-Haqq) say: <<Indeed, Allah does not forgive that association (shirk) be made with Him>>. He imagined that the duration of the punishment for polytheism would not end, but Allah did not say that. The polytheist must be punished and must dwell in Hell (Jahannam); he is not leaving the Fire, so his dwelling is eternal (mu'abbad al-sukna). But He did not address the termination of the period of wretched punishment within it. The fear is only of that [wretchedness], not of it being a permanent abode for those who inhabit it.

Thus, Allah spoke truly that the polytheist is seized by his polytheism. This is equivalent to the execution of a legal penalty (iqamat al-hadd) upon one for whom it is determined, whether in this world or the Hereafter. These are Divine Penalties (Hudud Ilahiyya) that the Real (al-Haqq) executes upon His servant if He does not forgive him their causes. Iblis was ignorant of the termination of the period of punishment for the polytheist due to his polytheism. For this reason, Iblis hopes for the Divine Mercy (al-Rahma al-Ilahiyya) which <<encompasses all things>>. His hope in it stems from the very nature of the favor (minna) due to its absolute nature, because he knows in himself that he is a monotheist (muwahhid). Allah only named him an unbeliever (kafir) in His saying: <<and he was among the unbelievers (al-kafirin)>> because he conceals from the servants the paths to their felicity (sa'ada) that the Law (Shar') brought for every person according to what he is capable of. Thus, He said concerning him: <<He refused and was arrogant, and he was among the unbelievers (al-kafirin)>>. He did not say 'among the polytheists' (al-mushrikin), because he fears Allah, the Lord of the Worlds.

### [The Argument of Jesus, peace be upon him, with Iblis]

Jesus, peace be upon him, said to Iblis when Iblis failed to make Jesus obey him, Iblis said to him: "O Jesus, say: 'There is no god but Allah'," striving to make him obey. Jesus, peace be upon him, said to him: "I say it, but not because of your saying it."

Iblis already knew that Hell (Jahannam) does not accept the eternity (khulud) of the People of Unity (Ahl al-Tawhid) within it, and that Allah will not leave a monotheist (muwahhid) in it, regardless of the path of his monotheism. Iblis relied on this extent regarding himself. Thus, he knew from one aspect and was ignorant from another, for no one knows a thing in all its aspects except Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, Who <<encompasses all things in Knowledge ('Ilm)>>, whether the thing is fixed (thabit), existent (mawjud), finite (mutanahi), or infinite (ghayr mutanahi).

> The Real (al-Haqq) said to me in my innermost being (damir):
> How ignorant are the creatures concerning matters!
> No one knows the matter except a person
> Who is an informer, knowing, expert,
> Prepared for guidance, ready,
> A noble one, insightful concerning the affairs of mankind.
> He has known the Real (al-Haqq) with the knowledge of direct experience (dhawq),
> Not by conjecture (hads) nor by mere perception (shu'ur).
> Neither distance nor proximity,
> Neither concealment nor manifestation.

### "The Ninth Connection" from the Treasuries of Generosity (Jūd)

The Exalted said: <<And the leg is wrapped around the leg (iltiffat al-saq bi-al-saq)>>. This is a wrapping that will not be undone, for the Exalted completed it by saying: <<To your Lord, that Day, is the driving (al-masaq)>>. He brought the Name (al-Rabb) which grants permanence (thabat). The matter is wrapped around the matter, and the driving is to the Lord (al-Rabb). Thus, the permanence of this wrapping in the Abode of the Hereafter (al-Dar al-Akhira) is necessary. The essence of the matter of this world is the essence of the matter of the Hereafter, except that the station (mawtan) of the Hereafter does not resemble the station of this world, due to the purification (takhliṣ) in the Hereafter that subsists through the existence of both abodes. Thus, the distinction occurred through the abode, yet all is Hereafter. The matter of this world is wrapped around the matter of the Hereafter, but not the essence of this world around the matter of the Hereafter, nor the essence of this world around the essence of the Hereafter.

Every abode has its people and community. The matter is what it is for all of them, even if the states (ahwal) differ. People in the Hereafter will continuously transition through states, just as they transitioned through states in this world. The Fixed Entities (al-A'yan al-Thabita) are permanent, for the Lord (al-Rabb) preserves them. Transition (Intiqal) is the comprehensive principle. What they transition into is another knowledge ('ilm), known from another perspective. Since the Hereafter is an Abode of Recompense (Dar Jaza'), just as this world was an Abode of Recompense for good and evil, what manifests in the Hereafter manifests as felicity (sa'ada) and wretchedness (shaqa'). Wretchedness is due to Divine Wrath (al-Ghadab al-Ilahi), and felicity is due to Divine Pleasure (al-Rida al-Ilahi). Pleasure is the extension of Mercy (Rahma) without end, while Wrath is cut off by the Prophetic Report (khabar nabawi). Thus, its ruling ends, but the ruling of Pleasure does not end, especially since...

### [That Man is Born upon the Innate Nature (Fitra), which is the Knowledge of the Lord's Existence]

We have previously stated in this book of ours that man is born upon the innate nature (fitra), which is the knowledge of the Lord's existence: that He is our Lord and we are His servants. And man is not seized [by death] when he is seized except after the unveiling of the veil (kashf al-ghita'), so he is not seized except as a believer (mu'min), nor is he resurrected except as a believer.

However, when Allah said: <<Their faith did not benefit them when they saw Our might (ba'sana)>>, they only believed so that that might might be repelled from them, but it was not repelled, and Allah seized them with that might. What is mentioned is that it does not benefit them in the Hereafter. This is supported by His saying: <<If only there had been a city that believed and whose faith benefited it, except the people of Jonah (Yunus). When they believed, when they saw the might, We removed from them the punishment of disgrace in the worldly life (al-hayat al-dunya)>>. This is the meaning of our statement: <<Their faith did not benefit them>> in lifting the might from them in the worldly life, as it benefited the people of Jonah. It did not address the Hereafter.

Despite this, Allah executes His penalties (hudud) upon His servants wherever and whenever He wills. Thus, the transition of people in the two abodes is established in their states: from bliss (na'im) to bliss, from torment ('adhab) to torment, and from torment to bliss, without a known duration for us. Allah has only informed us that we derive comfort from His saying concerning <<a Day whose measure is fifty thousand years>>, that this duration is the period for the execution of penalties. Allah knows best, for I have no knowledge of this through Unveiling (Kashf). May Allah have mercy on a servant whom the Real (al-Haqq) informs of the termination of the period of wretchedness (shaqa'), so that he may append it to this place in my book, for I have known this in general terms, without detail.

Since <<To your Lord, that Day, is the driving (al-masaq)>>, and the Lord (al-Rabb) is the Reconciler (al-Muslih), Allah will reconcile between His servants on the Day of Resurrection. Thus, it came in the Prophetic Report (khabar nabawi) concerning two men, one of whom has a right against the other. They stand before Allah the Exalted. The oppressed one says: "O Lord, take my grievance from this man." He says to him: "Raise your head." He sees abundant goodness. The oppressed one says: "O Lord, for whom is this?" He says: "For the one who gives Me the price." He says: "O Lord, who can afford the price of this?" He says to him: "You, by forgiving your brother." He says: "I have forgiven him." So he takes his hand, and they both enter Paradise. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said upon relating this report: <<So fear Allah and reconcile among yourselves, for Allah will reconcile between His servants on the Day of Resurrection>>.

If it is the nature of the Generous One (al-Karim) to reconcile between His servants with such a reconciliation, even to the extent that the oppressed one drops his right and forgives his brother, then Allah is more deserving of this attribute than the servant in abandoning accountability for His rights against His servants. Thus, He punishes whomever He wills for the injustice (zulm) against others, not for His own specific right. For this reason, the seizure for polytheism (shirk) is considered an injustice against others, for Allah does not seek victory for Himself; rather, He seeks victory for others, and for whomever He, Glory be to Him, wills to seek victory.

The partners (shuraka') will disown their followers on the Day of Resurrection. The Lord (al-Rabb) is also the Sustainer (al-Mughadhdhi) and the Educator (al-Murabbi). He educates His servants. It is the nature of the Educator to rectify the state of the one he educates. Some education involves pain, like one who strikes his child to discipline him; this is part of his education and seeking benefit for him so that it profits him in his station. Likewise, the penalties (hudud) of Allah are an education for His servants when Allah executes them upon them. He educates them through these for a felicity (sa'ada) that they possess in that, without them realizing it, just as a child does not realize the benefit of the striking by the one who educates him. The Lord (al-Rabb) is also the Master (al-Sayyid). The Master is more compassionate towards his servant than the servant is towards himself, for He knows his interests better. A Master will never strive to destroy his servant, because His mastery (siyada) is only valid through the existence of the servant, for it is a relative attribute (sifa idafiyya). To the extent that the related term (al-mudaf) ceases, the ruling of the term to which it is related (al-mudaf ilayh) ceases. This is like the Sultan: if his occupation is not constantly with the affairs of his subjects, then he has nothing of sovereignty (saltana) but the name, and he is deposed in reality (fi nafs al-amr), for the rank only accepts him as a Sultan under its conditions. To the extent that he occupies himself with his own amusement and pleasure, neglecting his subjects, he is merely a human among humans, with no share in sovereignty. He will be diminished in the Hereafter from the reward, glory, and loftiness of sovereignty to the extent that he neglected its right in this world through his amusement, play, hunting, and feigned heedlessness (taghaful) regarding the affairs of his subjects.

If the Sultan hears the plea of one of his subjects against him, but does not pay attention to that supplicant, nor judges in the matter according to what his request dictates, whether for him or against him, he has testified against himself by this action that he is deposed and is not a Sultan, and there is no difference between him and the common people. Such a thing only occurs from an ignorant Sultan who has no Gnosis (Ma'rifa) of the extent of what Allah has entrusted him with. It is no wonder that this action necessitates that its evil consequence (wabal) reverts upon him on the Day of Resurrection, and the argument (hujja) of his subjects is established against him before Allah. Thus, he remains ruined by his deed, and neither his amusement, nor his wealth, nor his sons, nor anything that distracted him from what sovereignty inherently demands will benefit him then.

As for the Lord (al-Rabb), Who is the Owner (al-Malik), due to the intensity of what this Name grants in considering what the rank deserves and fulfilling its right, the meaning of the specialization of this Name, the Lord (al-Rabb), to Whom is the driving (al-masaq) when the leg is wrapped around the leg (iltifaf al-saq bi-al-saq), has become clear to you in this context. By Him, the two matters were ordered, and the two transitions were established. Whoever knows the permanence of Existence (al-Wujud) and who is its Owner, Master, and Reconciler, and whose ruling is permanent within it, knows that the Lord is its Owner. Whoever knows the station of his servitude ('ubudiyya) knows the station of the mastery (siyada) of his Lord. Thus, he fears Him, hopes in Him, and believes Him in His granting of security, knowing that He is the Faithful, Truthful, Rich Master.

Whenever something collapses from the House of Existence (Bayt al-al-Wujud), this Master repairs it by the hand of His servant, because the servant is His instrument (ala) in that and the one employed. Rectification of what has collapsed occurs through his hand. His Master commands him in this, either by direct address (mushafaha), or by a message conveyed to him from the Master regarding its rectification, or by a state (surat hal) that dictates its rectification without depending on a command coming from the Master. This is like the commendable monasticism (rahbaniyya hasana) that those who initiated it innovated; they are rewarded for it because the form of the state conforms to what is in the Master's Self, even if He did not command it in the Divine Laws (Nawamis) for the people of the interval periods (Ahl al-Fatarat).

The Law (Shar') only came for the interests (masalih) of this world and the Hereafter. The Hereafter is only known through the reports of its Creator, and that it is contingent (mumkina) according to the judgment of the intellect. This world and its interests are known because they are actual and witnessed. Thus, there is scope for examining its interests, unlike the Hereafter. The interests of this world do not depend on what the interests of the Hereafter depend on. For this reason, no community has been devoid of a Divine Law (Namus) to follow, because the seeking of interests is inherent in the animal, so how much more so in man, the possessor of thought and vision? Whoever reflects upon this connection (wasl) will see wonders and acquire a knowledge ('ilm) that grants him elevation in this world and the Hereafter. To it is joined the knowledge of Gathering and Separation (al-Jam' wa al-Farq) which is in the very essence of Gathering (Ayn al-Jam'), the knowledge of States and Affairs (al-Ahwal wa al-Shu'un), the knowledge of the Two Times (al-Zamanayn), the knowledge specific to the Cosmos (al-Kawn), the knowledge of the Hearts (Qulub) that encompassed the Real (al-Haqq), Glorious is His Majesty, the knowledge of what causes the Subsistence (al-Baqa') of this Existence (al-Wujud)—meaning all existents—and the knowledge of the Outcome (al-'Aqiba). It is a noble connection.

> If the servitude ('ubuda) of every servant is sound,
> Mastery (siyada) becomes sound for him in Existence (al-Wujud).
> He rules like his Master, and there appear
> Upon him thereby the signs of increase.
> The tongue of the state (lisan al-hal) informs us about him
> That the matter in him is from Witnessing (al-Shuhud).
> Faces submit to him when he manifests,
> Just as the angels submitted with prostration.
> He ascends in elevation and is humbled in glory,
> So he is called the Desired (al-Murad) and the Desirer (al-Murid).

### "The Tenth Connection" from the Treasuries of Generosity (Jūd)

This is the connection of Direct Experiences (al-Adhwaq), which is the knowledge of modalities (al-kayfiyyat). These are not spoken of except among their possessors when they agree upon a specific terminology (istilah) concerning them. If they do not agree upon that, they cannot be spoken of among the tasters (al-dha'iqin). This only occurs in the knowledge of what is other than Allah, which is not perceived except through direct experience (dhawqan), such as sensible things and the pleasure derived from them, and the pleasure found in knowledge gained from intellectual contemplation (al-nazar al-fikri). In this, terminology is possible in a close manner.

As for the direct experience (dhawq) that occurs in the witnessing (mushahada) of the Real (al-Haqq), no terminology can be applied to it, for it is the direct experience of the Secrets (adhwaq al-asrar), and it is outside of intellectual and sensory direct experience. For things—meaning everything other than Allah—have likenesses (amthal) and similarities (ashbah), so terminology can be applied to them for mutual understanding among every taster who has a taste of direct experience in them, of whatever type of perception it may be. But the Creator (al-Bari') <<There is nothing like Him (laysa ka-mithlihi shay')>>. Thus, it is impossible for terminology to encompass Him. For what one person witnesses of Him is not exactly what another person witnesses of Him in a single totality. The Gnostics (al-'Arifun) know Him by this. A Gnostic of the matter cannot convey to another Gnostic what he witnesses of his Lord, because every Gnostic witnesses the One Who has no likeness, and conveyance only occurs through likenesses.

If they shared a single form, they could agree upon terminology concerning it as they wished. If one person accepted that, it would be permissible for the entire world to accept it. But He does not manifest (yatajalla) in a single form to two Gnostics. However, Allah has raised some of His servants to degrees (darajat) that He did not grant to His other servants for whom these degrees were not sound—these are the common people (al-'amma) among the People of Vision (Ahl al-Ru'ya). He manifests to them in the forms of likenesses (suwar al-amthal). For this reason, the community (Umma) unites upon a single creed ('aqd) concerning Allah. Every individual in that specific group believes concerning Allah what the others believe, such as those who agreed among the Ash'aris, the Mu'tazilis, the Hanbalis, and the Ancients. They agreed upon a single matter about which that group did not differ, so it was permissible for them to agree upon terminology concerning what they agreed upon.

As for the Gnostics (al-'Arifun), the People of Allah (Ahl Allah), they knew that Allah does not manifest (yatajalla) in a single form to two persons, nor in a single form twice. Thus, the matter was not fixed for them, because every person has a unique Theophany (tajalli). Man saw this from himself: when He manifested to him in one form, and then manifested to him in a different form, he learned from this Theophany what he did not learn from the other Theophany of the Real (al-Haqq). This is always the case in every Theophany. He knew that the matter is thus in reality, both concerning himself and concerning others. Therefore, he cannot specify a terminology for it that would be beneficial between those conversing. They know, but what they know cannot be spoken. Nor is it within the power of the possessors of this most glorious station—than which there is no higher station among contingent things—to assign a word to it that indicates what he has known of it, except for what the Exalted Himself established, which is His saying, Mighty and Majestic: <<There is nothing like Him (laysa ka-mithlihi shay')>>. He negated likeness. Thus, no form in which He manifests to someone resembles another form.

> The matter is too exalted to be known and then recounted,
> And too majestic for terminology to encompass it.
> Intellects are ignorant of it when they see it,
> Tongues express it, so the eloquent one cried out,
> From people who imitate intellects,
> In a place where rectification cannot occur.
> So they gathered upon Him through thought,
> Based on ignorance, and felicity betrayed them.
> But the Gnostics spoke of what they saw,
> And they did not agree on terminology, so success came to them.
> There is nothing like Him in the Cosmos (Kawn),
> And for Him, there is nothing from us but release [from limitation].

By our restriction (taqyid), we have ruled upon Him with absolute freedom (itlaq). As for the matter in itself, it is not described by restriction nor by absolute freedom, but rather by general Existence (Wujud 'Amm). He is the essence ('ayn) of things, yet things are not His essence. Nothing manifests unless its identity (huwiyya) is the essence of that thing. If His Existence (Wujud) is of this nature, how can He accept absolute freedom or restriction? This is how the Gnostics (al-'Arifun) know Him. Whoever declares Him absolutely free has not known Him, and whoever restricts Him has been ignorant of Him.

> Allah, nothing besides Him is witnessed by us,
> He is the Transcendent (al-Munazzah) and the Gatherer between us.
> Restriction and absolute freedom are one in Him,
> And both are rulings upon Him, for Him, by us.
> Look at Him with His Eye, if you are a possessor of intellect,
> You will find Him manifested in the innermost secret (sarira).
> This is the clear Real (al-Haqq) for one who sees
> What I have seen, demonstrated and clarified.

### [That Allah the Exalted did not give wings to the Spirits (Arwah) except to the Angels among them]

Know that Allah the Exalted did not give wings (ajniha) to the Spirits (al-Arwah) except to the Angels (al-Mala'ika) among them, because they are the ambassadors (sufara') from the Divine Presence of Command (Hadrat al-Amr) to His Creation (Khalq). They must have means by which they descend and ascend, for the subject of wisdom (hikma) dictates this. So He gave them wings according to their ranks (maratib) in what they convey from the Divine Presence of the Real (Hadrat al-Haqq) or what they ascend to from the presence of Creation (Hadrat al-Khalq). They move back and forth between Creation and Command. For this reason, they said: <<And we do not descend except by the command of your Lord>>. So know that.

When these ambassadors descend upon the hearts (qulub), if they find them pure hearts receptive to goodness, they grant them knowledge ('ilm) of what they brought, according to the capacity of their preparedness. If they find them defiled hearts in which there is no goodness, they forbid them from remaining in that state and command them to purity, according to what the Lawgiver (al-Shari') stipulated for them: if it is in the knowledge of Allah, then through the knowledge of Him that thought seeks and that the Prophetic Report (khabar nabawi) brought from Allah; and if it is in the Cosmos (al-Akwan), then through the knowledge of rulings (ahkam) and their beliefs. This ruling is binding upon him when the hearts are found.

But if they do not find them, like the hearts of the Gnostics (al-'Arifun) who are in <<There is nothing like Him (laysa ka-mithlihi shay')>>, the angels do not know where they have gone. These are the ones who receive from Allah, from the specific aspect, the states (ahwal) they are in. They are ignorant [of the source] and are held accountable for what they bring. It is from here that Khidr took his knowledge. These people are criticized, but they do not criticize anyone except through the tongue of the Law (lisan al-Shar'). It is the tongue of the Law that criticizes, not them. This is like the one who glorifies Allah with His praise (al-musabbih bi-hamd Allah). Allah is the One Who praised Himself with what He knows Himself to be upon. If a person acts presumptuously and deduces a praise for Him that did not come in that wording through a Divine address, then he has not glorified Him with His praise, but with what he deduced from himself. Thus, he falls short of the degree that is proper. Say what He said about Himself, and do not add to the number, even if it is good. I have clarified for you that if you act upon this, you will be among the People of the Real (Ahl al-Haqq). <<And Allah speaks the Truth, and He guides to the way>>.

### "The Eleventh Connection" from the Treasuries of Generosity (Jūd)

> The Fire (al-Nar) is two fires: the Fire of Allah and the flame,
> And the Abode (al-Dar) is two abodes: the Abode of triumph and the Abode of ruin.
> All of them are a cause originating from the being of their originator,
> So fear the being (kawn), do not fear the cause.
> Fear Knowledge ('Ilm), for Knowledge rules it,
> And incline toward peace (silm), do not incline toward war (harb).

### [That the Real (al-Haqq) brought the Fire (al-Nar) in absolute terms and brought it attributed]

Know, may Allah grant you knowledge, that the Real (al-Haqq) brought the Fire (al-Nar) in absolute terms, such as His saying, "The Fire," with the definite article wherever it occurs, and He brought it attributed. Among these is a fire He attributed to Allah, such as His saying: <<The Fire of Allah (Nār Allāh), kindled>>, and a fire He attributed to other than Allah, such as His saying: <<For them is the Fire of Hell (Nār Jahannam)>>. Then He described this Fire with descriptions and reported about it with reports of kindling, encompassing, and so forth. He established a ruling for it outwardly, making it a container (zarf), such as His saying: <<Then for him is the Fire of Hell, abiding therein eternally>>. Thus, He brought the container. And a ruling inwardly, which is that the servant's outward self is a container for it, and it is <<The Fire of Allah, kindled, which mounts up to the hearts (al-af'ida)>>. The hearts are the inward part of man. Thus, it manifests in the heart of man. From this inward fire, the outward fire appeared. The servant is the originator (mansha') of the two fires in both states. Nothing torments him except what he originated. Likewise, nothing angered the Real (al-Haqq) except what He created. Were it not for Creation (al-Khalq), the Real would not have been angry. Were it not for the accountable one (al-mukallaf) who originated the form of the two fires through his outward and inward action, he would not have been tormented by fire. In reality and correct contemplation, no one has wronged anyone.

> So do not act, so you will not be wretched,
> Be a servant ('abd) and be the Real (Haqq).
> There is nothing there but what I have said,
> So look, and you will see the Real (al-Haqq).
> The torment of Creation is by Creation,
> Whether you were the Real (Haqq) or Creation (Khalq).

### And from that:

> The Fire is from you, and by deeds you kindle it,
> Just as by righteous deeds you extinguish it immediately.
> By nature, you are always fleeing from it,
> Yet in every state, you originate it within yourself.
> Does your soul (nafs) not have an intellect in its disposition?
> I have come to inform it today, before death, for Allah told us
> That on the Day of the Presentation of Creation, He will fill it.

### [That Allah will be angry on the Day of Resurrection with a wrath unlike any He was angry with before]

When the Exalted mentioned, through the tongues of His Messengers, peace be upon them, that Allah will be angry on the Day of Resurrection with a wrath (ghadab) unlike any He was angry with before, and unlike any He will be angry with after, and that when the Fire says: <<Is there any more?>>, because He promised to fill it, and it is the Abode of Wrath, He said: "The Compeller (al-Jabbar) will place His Foot (qadam) in it," and it will say: "Enough! Enough!"—meaning, "I am full." That Foot is none other than the Wrath of Allah. When He places it in it, it is filled, for it is the Abode of Wrath.

The Real (al-Haqq) is characterized by expansive Mercy (al-Rahma al-Wasi'a). His Mercy encompassed Hell (Jahannam) through what He filled it with of His Wrath. Thus, it is delighted by what it contains. And Allah had mercy on those within it—meaning, in the Fire, who are its people—so He makes for them a bliss (na'im) within it from this Mercy, just as Hell was blessed by the Divine Wrath (al-Ghadab al-Ilahi) placed within it. For a creature whose reality is to perish cannot be filled by a creature; everything that enters it is annihilated by it, as mentioned regarding the scorching of skins. Thus, nothing fills a creature except the Real (al-Haqq). The Wrath of Allah is the Real (Haqq), so He bestowed favor upon Hell with it and placed it within it, and it was filled with the Real (Haqq), just as Paradise was filled with the Pleasure and Mercy of the Real.

> The Real (al-Haqq) has encompassed all things,
> Because He is the essence ('ayn) of all things.
> So you see nothing in it but the Real (Haqq),
> In every light and every shadow.

### And from that:

> The Fire of Allah is nothing but my Existence (Wujud),
> And the Fire of Hell is the possessor of the fuel.

By deities that people worship,
And they remain therein under the rule of eternity.

I saw in this connection (وصل) a vision that terrified me in the event (الواقعة). The Sura of the Event (Al-Waqi'ah) was recited to me by a righteous believing woman, presented to me. The form of her recitation was: *A company of the former people, a company of the latter people* (ثُلَّةٌ من الْأَوَّلِينَ ثُلَّةٌ من الْآخِرِينَ), omitting the conjunction *waw* (واو العطف). I had no secret knowledge of this before. I asked her to read it with the letter *waw*, but she did not. I returned to myself and understood what The Real (الحق) had alerted me to in that omission: the separation (الاقتطاع) between the world (العالم). When the *waw* is present, it observes the commonality in the apparent form and the primary concept. When the *waw* is removed, it observes the distinction and singularity (الانفراد) which constitutes the reality (حقيقة) of that thing, because it has no reality except through that by which it is distinguished. Thus, I knew what He intended by her omission of the *waw* in her recitation, and that is Allah, so that it may be known that <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْ‏ءٌ>> (There is nothing whatever like unto Him), even with the existence of things, and that whether they exist or not, He is negated of similitude (المماثلة). The matter then remains: is He negated of suitability (المناسبة) or not? Because creation (الإيجاد) without suitability is inconceivable. Since creation has occurred and the creature (المخلوق) has appeared, we know that suitability (المناسب) is necessary, yet it does not grant similitude at all, because all creation belongs to Allah, and all command belongs to Allah, so there is no partnership. Thus, similitude is negated, even with the existence of suitability which The Real seeks by His Essence (بذاته). Every creation attributed to another creation is metaphorical (مجاز) and a veiling image (صورة حجابية), so that the knowledgeable may be distinguished from the ignorant, and so that creatures may be favored one above the other, allowing gratitude (الشكر) to be realized by the favored one (الفاضل) and seeking and need (الافتقار) by the less favored one (المفضول). The favored one is increased due to his gratitude, and the less favored one is given due to his seeking. Thus, all are in increase (مزيد), and the differentiation (التفاضل) does not cease; every degree the favored one ascends through increase, the less favored one ascends behind him, seeking that degree. Thus, all are in ascent without catching up (من غير لحوق).

The Real called me from my own Being (وجودي)
In every state, upon Witnessing (الشهود).
"Your Essence (ذاتكم) is filled," we said,
"Impossible fullness! <<هَلْ من مَزِيدٍ>> (Is there any more?)"
Nothing fills the cosmos except the One who
Has bestowed Being (الوجود) upon creation.
And that is The Real (الحق), there is none other than Him;
The rank of the Lord is not like that of the servants.
He who knows The Real by knowledge of taste (علم ذوق)
Has not known the delight of Prostration (السجود).

The Fire of Hell (نار جهنم) causes the cooking of skins and the burning of bodies. The Fire of Allah (نار الله) is a represented, embodied fire because it is the result of inner, spiritual acts (أعمال معنوية باطنة). The Fire of Hell is the result of outer, sensory acts (أعمال حسية ظاهرة). This is so that the person characterized by both may combine the two punishments, just as was done with the People of the Covenant (أهل الجزية) when they paid it <<عَنْ يَدٍ وهُمْ صاغِرُونَ>> (out of hand, and they are humbled). Thus, they were punished by the torment of the removal of wealth from their hands, combined with the humiliation and subjugation (الصغار والقهر), which is the torment of their souls due to the distress they find in that. Do you not see the hypocrite (المنافق) in <<الدَّرْكِ الْأَسْفَلِ من النَّارِ>> (the lowest abyss of the Fire)? He is in the Fire of Allah due to his persistence in disbelief (الكفر), and he has no place in the first abyss due to the apparent deeds he performed. This is contrary to the disbeliever (الكافر), who has both the highest and lowest parts of Hell (جهنم). He has no one to protect him from the Fire of Allah nor from the Fire of Hell. As for the ruling concerning the one who denied it [the truth] outwardly but was certain of The Real (الحق) and believed in it inwardly, his punishment is the opposite or reverse of the hypocrite's torment. He is knowledgeable of The Real, realizing it within himself, but he did not manifest that upon the exterior of his existence (نشأته), thus displaying the opposite of what he concealed. The Fire only seeks from humanity the one upon whom the image of The Real (صورة حق) has not appeared, neither outwardly nor inwardly. Thus, knowledge (العلم) is to the inner being (الباطن) as action (العمل) is to the outer being (الظاهر), and ignorance (الجهل) is to the inner being as the abandonment of obligation (ترك الواجب) is to the outer being. Here, the degrees and causes of Divine accountability (المؤاخذات الإلهية) for His servants in the Hereafter become clear to man. When the limits (الحدود) are fulfilled, mercy (الرحمة) encompasses all from the Treasury of Generosity (خزانة الجود). This is His saying: <<فَأَمَّا الَّذِينَ شَقُوا فَفِي النَّارِ ... خالِدِينَ فِيها ما دامَتِ السَّماواتُ والْأَرْضُ>> (As for those who are wretched, they will be in the Fire... abiding therein as long as the heavens and the earth endure). This is the temporal limit (الحد الزماني), because the heavens and the earth must inevitably be replaced (التبديل), and the duration ends at that point. This applies to every human being from the time of his obligation (تكليفه) until the Day of Replacement, because he is not addressed concerning the permanence of the heavens and the earth before obligation. This applies to both the felicitous (السعيد) and the wretched (الشقي). They remain in the results of their deeds for this specified duration. When it ends, the bliss of commensurate recompense (نعيم الجزاء الوفاق) and the torment of recompense cease. These people then transition to the bliss of Divine Graces (المنن الإلهية), which Allah did not link to deeds nor restrict to one group over another. This is <<عَطاءً غَيْرَ مَجْذُوذٍ>> (an unfailing gift), which has no duration that ends with its termination, just as disbelief and faith end here with the termination of the obligated person's life. The imposition of limits upon the wretched and the recompense of bliss upon the felicitous ends with the duration of the heavens and the earth, <<إِلَّا ما شاءَ رَبُّكَ>> (except what your Lord wills) concerning the wretched, for <<إِنَّ رَبَّكَ فَعَّالٌ لِما يُرِيدُ>> (Indeed, your Lord is the Doer of what He intends). And thus, the matter occurred according to what the Divine Will (المشيئة الإلهية) related to. Since He did not say concerning the wretched, "an unfailing torment," as He said concerning the felicitous, we know—by the mention of the duration of the heaven and the earth, the ruling of the Will concerning the wretched, and the turning away from mentioning the torment—that wretchedness has a duration to which its ruling terminates and ceases for the wretched upon its cessation, and that the recompense of the felicitous is similar. Then, the Divine Graces and Satisfaction (الرضي الإلهي) encompass everyone, regardless of the station they are in, for bliss is nothing but what the temperament accepts and what the souls desire; places have no effect on this. Wherever the temperament finds suitability (ملاءمة الطبع) and the attainment of purpose (نيل الغرض), that is bliss for its possessor. Know this. The subject of the exception (الاستثناء) is known for both groups: concerning the bliss the disbeliever enjoyed in the worldly life by attaining his purposes and the health of his body, and concerning the believer's failure to attain his purposes and his illnesses in the world. All of this is from the time of obligation (تكليف) for each of the two groups. And Allah <<يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (speaks the Truth, and He guides to the Way).

### The Twelfth Connection (الوصل) from the Treasuries of Generosity (خزائن الجود): The Divine Neglect (الإهمال الإلهي)

Its possessor does not know what is destined for him. For every servant who deserved punishment (العقاب) for violating what the Messenger brought to him, Allah has granted him respite (أمهله) and has not seized him. He is under the rule of the authority of the Name The Forbearing (الاسم الحليم), so he is like the neglected one (المهمل). He does not know whether Providence (العناية) will precede for him with forgiveness and pardon before the Divine limit (الحد الإلهي) is established upon him by decree, or whether he will be seized and the limits of his crimes established upon him until a known term. Since this possibility is permissible for the one Allah grants respite, the image of the possessor of this description is the image of the neglected one. For neglect (الإهمال) on the part of The Real (الحق) is not valid, since in Allah's prior knowledge (علم الله السابق), he is either forgiven or held accountable for what he committed against himself. Thus, he is in danger and unaware of what was decreed for him in the Book of Past Judgment. The judgment rules over the just judge just as it rules over the judged, either by seizure or by pardon, concerning the person who is in a state and condition that necessitates one of the two matters we mentioned. This applies only to the one whom Allah has granted respite and did not hold accountable at the time of the transgression. The anticipation itself is sufficient torment for the gnostic (العارف) who sins and is granted respite, who is in the image of the neglected one, because he does not know the outcome of the matter concerning him. There is no community (طائفة) except that it is under a legal, judicial law (ناموس شرعي حكمي) or a conventional, judicial ordinance (وضع حكمي). No nation is free from a transgression against its law, whatever that law may be.

The perpetrator of this transgression is never free from the anticipation of pardon or accountability, according to what the setter of his law has decreed upon him. Laws (النواميس) have encompassed all nations, which is His saying: <<وإِنْ من أُمَّةٍ إِلَّا خَلا فِيها نَذِيرٌ>> (And there is no nation but that a warner has passed within it). This warner (نذير) is either a warner by Allah's command and Will, or a warner by Allah's Will but not by a revelation (وحي) sent down to him by which he knows it is from Allah. Allah's command is related to the very existence of the warning within him. So, it was said to his warning, "Be," in this servant, and it was. Thus, he found the warning within himself but did not know where it came from. This is the difference between the Divine Law (الشرع الإلهي) brought by the Messengers from Allah and what the sages of the ages (حكماء الأعصار) established for their followers for their own benefit. Whoever fulfills the right of his law, respects it, and stops at its limit, seeking Allah's pleasure, has done well in his action. And Allah does not waste <<أَجْرَ من أَحْسَنَ عَمَلًا>> (the reward of those who do good deeds). *Ihsan* (الإحسان) is that you worship Allah as if you see Him, or know that He sees you. This is the defining limit (الحد الضابط) for excellence in action. Anything other than this is a bad deed (سوء عمله). If someone is among those <<زُيِّنَ لَهُ سُوءُ عَمَلِهِ فَرَآهُ حَسَناً>> (whose evil deed is made fair-seeming to him, so he sees it as good), then it must be one of two cases: either his seeing the evil deed as good is after an exertion (اجتهاد) that fulfills what is within the capacity of that striving person—in which case he has fulfilled the matter its due right and is the possessor of a good deed, and the ruling of his evil deed being seen as good in his striving is the same ruling as the one who correctly hits the truth (المصيب للحق), who receives two rewards—and this person whose deed is made fair-seeming to him receives one reward. Or, if it is not based on fulfilling exertion to the extent of his capacity, and he sees it as good without exertion, then he is subject to the Will (المشيئة). He does not know how his life will conclude or what his fate will be during the period of the establishment of limits in this world and the Hereafter. He is one of those who have been extravagant (أسرف) against themselves. If he despairs (قنط) of Allah's mercy, he has not fulfilled the matter its due right and has thought ill of his Lord, and the Lord is according to the servant's expectation of Him. Allah has forbidden the extravagant person from despair. Is his despair, by committing this forbidden act that comes after his extravagance, considered to have an effect that prevents forgiveness from reaching him, or is its ruling the same as every other extravagance? This person is also granted respite (ممهل) and does not know the outcome of the matter, if the observer is fair, because He said: <<إِنَّ الله يَغْفِرُ الذُّنُوبَ جَمِيعاً>> (Indeed, Allah forgives all sins), whether despair is absent or present, except for the polytheist (المشرك) who did not exert himself in seeking the absence of multiplicity (الكثرة) in the Divine Name, for he must be held accountable. Thus, it is incumbent upon the rational person (العاقل) to know the temporal durations (المدد الزمانية), the differences between times, ages, and eras, and what occurs of that <<إِلى‏ أَجَلٍ مُسَمًّى>> (until a specified term) concerning the individuals referred to as times, and what occurs without a specified term, and what is the Truth (الحق) that necessitates gratitude, and what is the Truth that necessitates patience. And Allah <<يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (speaks the Truth, and He guides to the Way).

### [Indeed, Faith (الإيمان) is a general matter, and likewise Disbelief (الكفر)]

As for Faith (الإيمان), it is a general matter, and likewise Disbelief (الكفر), which is its opposite. Allah has named a believer (مؤمنا) the one who believes in The Real (الحق), and He has named a believer the one who believes in falsehood (الباطل). He has named a disbeliever (كافرا) the one who disbelieves in Allah, and He has named a disbeliever the one who disbelieves in the idol (الطاغوت). He clarified the destiny of both groups and the path that came with its clarification, supporting it with proofs of its authenticity that it is from Allah, the One hoped for in every religion (ملة) and sect (نحلة) and by every group. Righteous deeds (الأعمال الصالحة) are headed by faith, and they are subordinate to it, whatever the faith may be. There is nothing more obscure in existential matters (الأمور الوجودية) than this issue, because Allah linked the evil deed (العمل السيئ) with adornment (التزيين) so that the doer sees it as good and takes it as a righteous deed. And <<عَلَى الله قَصْدُ السَّبِيلِ>> (Upon Allah is the direction of the Way). The definite article (Alif and Lam) is used for comprehensiveness (الشمول) in the word *al-sabil* (the Way), for they are all ways seen by the one who strives (جاهد) for Allah. That striving makes the Divine Ways (السبل الإلهية) clear to him, so he follows the one that is most suitable for himself, excuses creation for the ways they are upon, and becomes singular with Allah. Thus, he is upon a light from Allah.

If Allah is known through His Act (فعله),
Then His neglect (إهماله) is the very essence of His granting respite (إمهاله).
One eye sees Him in His detail (بتفصيله),
And another eye sees Him in His totality (بإجماله).
So, some people are under the rule of His Excellence (إحسانه),
And some people are under the rule of His Majesty (إجلاله).
He contracts a person through His making known (بتعريفه),
And He expands a person through His neglect (بإهماله).
Glory be to the One whose ruling is single,
Whether by His turning away or by His turning toward.
Glory be to the One whose Excellence (إحسانه) is universal,
Whether by His showing favor or by His showing favor.
And everyone, by his preparation (إعداده), is receptive
To his loss and to His grace (لإفضاله).

And Allah <<يَدْعُوا إِلى‏ دارِ السَّلامِ ويَهْدِي من يَشاءُ إِلى‏ صِراطٍ مُسْتَقِيمٍ>> (invites to the Home of Peace and guides whom He wills to a straight path).

### The Thirteenth Connection from the Treasuries of Generosity

The outcome of the matter is the return from Multiplicity (الكثرة) to The One (الواحد), for both the believer and the polytheist. The believer who is granted the Unveiling (كشف) of things as they truly are is granted this, which is His saying: <<فَكَشَفْنا عَنْكَ غِطاءَكَ فَبَصَرُكَ الْيَوْمَ حَدِيدٌ>> (Then We removed from you your covering, and your sight, this Day, is sharp). This occurs before his departure from the world. No one is seized except upon an Unveiling (كشف) when he is seized, and he inclines toward The Real (الحق) at that moment.

The Real is Unity (التوحيد) and faith in Him. Whoever attains this Certainty (اليقين) before the Agony of Death (الاحتضار) is assured of his felicity and its continuity, for Certainty derived from sound contemplation and clear Unveiling (الكشف الصريح) prevents him from deviating from The Real. He is upon clear evidence and insight. But whoever attains this Certainty during the Agony of Death is subject to the Will (المشيئة), even though the outcome is felicity, but only after enduring hardships for those who are seized for their sins. The Agony of Death does not occur until one witnesses the matter to which creation transitions. If he has not witnessed that, then death has not attended him, and it is not the Agony of Death. Whoever believes or repents before that Agony of Death, even by a single breath, that faith and repentance benefit him with Allah in the Hereafter, and his state upon the seizure of his soul is the state of one who has no sin. Whether he was led to this by severe pain or illness that caused him to abandon his hope for worldly life, or by something else, he is a believing penitent, and that benefits him, for he is not in the Agony of Death. He only believed or repented due to a leaven (خميرة) that was in his inner being (باطنه) and heart, of which he was unaware. He only inclined toward what he inclined to because of a matter that was in his soul, whose ruling had not appeared on his exterior, and which was not in his soul except in that singular time (الزمن الفرد) that came in the time immediately preceding the Agony of Death, which necessitates the faith that results in being subject to the Will.

How great is the difference between one decreed to felicity,
And one upon whom His Will (مشيئته) passes judgment.
That one is a precious, sanctified deliverance,
And this one is upon a state whose reality (حقيقته) was shown to him.
Were it not for Him, His path (طريقته) would not have been made clear to him,
Nor would His creation (خليقته) have ever witnessed Him.

### [Indeed, Allah has established two Resurrections (قيامتين) in the Cosmos (الكون): a Minor Resurrection and a Major Resurrection]

When the servant transitions from the worldly life to the life of the Greater Presentation (العرض الأكبر), Allah Almighty has established two Resurrections (قيامتين) in the Cosmos (الكون): a Minor Resurrection (قيامة صغرى) and a Major Resurrection (قيامة كبرى). The Minor Resurrection is the servant's transition from the worldly life to the life of the Isthmus (البرزخ) in the represented body (الجسد الممثل). This is His saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Whoever dies, his Resurrection has begun."

Whoever is among the People of Vision (أهل الرؤية) will see his Lord.

For the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said when warning his community about the Dajjal (Antichrist): "No one sees Allah until he dies."

The Major Resurrection (القيامة الكبرى) is the Resurrection of the Raising (البعث) and the Greatest Gathering (الحشر الأعظم) in which people are assembled. In the Major Resurrection, man is either questioned, held accountable, closely scrutinized in his reckoning, or not closely scrutinized. The latter is the easy reckoning (الحساب اليسير), which is the presentation of deeds to the servant without scrutiny. Scrutiny (المناقشة) is the questioning about the underlying reasons (العلل) for the deeds. Questioning is general for everyone, even the Messengers, as He said: <<يَوْمَ يَجْمَعُ الله الرُّسُلَ فَيَقُولُ ما ذا أُجِبْتُمْ>> (The Day when Allah will assemble the Messengers and say, "What was the response you received?"). Questioning is of two types: questioning to confirm blessings, in the manner of The Real's intimacy (مباسطة الحق) with the questioned, who then finds delight in the questioning; and questioning in the manner of reproach, also to confirm blessings, which causes distress.

The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to his companions when they ate dates and water due to hunger: "You will surely be questioned about the delight of this day."

This questioning is directed as a warning and a glad tiding to specific people, namely the attendees of that gathering, and it is an alert to the state of affairs concerning everyone. After this confirmation, Allah only created the world for inherent felicity (للسعادة بالذات). Wretchedness occurred for those upon whom it fell by way of accident (بحكم العرض), because the pure Good (الخير المحض) in which there is no evil is the Being (وجود) of The Real, who granted existence to the world. Nothing issues from Him except what is suitable, which is Good exclusively. Therefore, the world inherently possesses Good. However, because the world was subject to the ruling of possibility (الإمكان)—due to its capacity for either of the two extremes (existence or non-existence) interchangeably—it was not in the rank of the Necessary Being by His Essence (الواجب الوجود لذاته). Thus, it was subject to the evil, which is the failure to attain purpose and the lack of suitability of temperament (ملاءمة الطبع). This occurred because its possibility (إمكانه) does not prevent it from non-existence. By this measure, evil appeared in the world. It appeared only from the side of the possible (الممكن), not from the side of The Real. For this reason,

The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said in his supplication to Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: "All good is in Your hands, and evil is not attributed to You."

Rather, evil is attributed to creation (الخلق) from the perspective of its possibility.

By the Essence (ذات) of The Real, we are the felicitous (السعدا),
And by the place of creatures (الورى), wretchedness (الشقا) occurred.
The meeting with The Real (لقاء الحق) is a necessary truth,
So rejoice in all good in the meeting!
For us, from ourselves, is Annihilation (فناء) and Subsistence (بقاء),
And for us, from Him, is Being (وجود) and meeting.
He is Good, having no visible opposite,
So when Good meets with Good,
Everything that was becomes good,
The path of evil and the causes of piety (التقا).

### [That bodies (الأجسام) are the tombs (نواويس) of souls (الأرواح)]

Know that bodies (الأجسام) are the tombs (نواويس) of souls (الأرواح) and their tastes. They are what veil the souls from witnessing and being witnessed, so they neither see nor are seen except by leaving these tombs through Annihilation (فناء) from them, not separation. When the soul is annihilated from witnessing them—while it possesses sight—it witnesses its Originator (موجدها) by witnessing itself. "Whoever knows himself knows his Lord." Likewise, whoever witnesses himself witnesses his Lord. He transitions from the Certainty of Knowledge (يقين علم) to the Certainty of Sight (يقين عين). When he is returned to his tomb, he is returned to the Certainty of Truth (يقين حق) from the Certainty of Sight, not to the Certainty of Knowledge. From this, man learns the distinction made by The Real through His truthful reports concerning the Truth of Certainty (حق اليقين), the Eye of Certainty (عين اليقين), and the Knowledge of Certainty (علم اليقين). Thus, every ruling settles in its proper rank for him, and things are not confused for him, and he knows that the reports have not lied to him. Whoever knows Allah by this path has known and understood the wisdom of forming the pearl (الجوهر) in the oyster shell (الصدف) from sweet water (ماء فرات) in salty, bitter water (ملح أجاج). His shell is his body, and his saltiness is his nature (طبيعته). For this reason, the ruling of nature appears upon his shell, for saltiness is whiteness, which is equivalent to the light (النور) by which unveiling occurs. Realize this by this proof. And <<عَلَى الله قَصْدُ السَّبِيلِ>> (Upon Allah is the direction of the Way).

### The Fourteenth Connection from the Treasuries of Generosity

It strikes the ears, grants enjoyment, and combines the low ground (القاع) and the high ground (اليفاع). Since the intended purpose of the Cosmos (العالم) was the Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل), the animal human (الإنسان الحيوان) was also part of the Cosmos, resembling the Perfect Human in natural existence (النشأة الطبيعية). The Realities (الحقائق) that the human being gathered were scattered throughout the Cosmos. The Real (الحق) called them from the entire Cosmos, and they gathered, and from their collection came the human being. Thus, he is their treasury. The faces of the Cosmos are directed toward this human treasury to see what appeared from the call of The Real with all these Realities. They saw an image of upright stature, straight movement, and defined directions. No one in the Cosmos had seen an image like this human image. From that time, the fiery spirits (الأرواح النارية) and the angels (الملائكة) took form in the image of man. This is His saying: <<فَتَمَثَّلَ لَها بَشَراً سَوِيًّا>> (Then he appeared to her as a man in all respects), and the saying of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: "And sometimes the Angel appears to me as a man."

Spirits (الأرواح) only take form (تتشكل) in the images they know, and they know nothing of these images except through Witnessing (الشهود). Thus, spirits used to take form in every image in the Cosmos except the image of man before man was created. Although spirits possess conception (التصور), they do not possess the Formative Power (القوة المصورة) as man does. The Formative Power is subordinate to the thought (الفكرة), which is an attribute of the thinking power (القوة المفكرة). Conception for the spirits is an attribute of the essence of the psychic spirits (الأرواح النفسية), not the spiritual ones (المعنوية), and not due to a Formative Power they possess.
