However, even though conception is intrinsic (ذاتيا) to them, they only conceive of what they have perceived of the images of the natural world (العالم الطبيعي). For this reason, the spirits above Nature (ما فوق الطبيعة) do not accept conception, because they have no knowledge of the images of natural forms. This applies only to the Soul (النفس), the Intellect (العقل), and the Cherubic Angels (الملائكة المهيمون), both worldly and otherworldly. Those above Nature do not witness the images of the Cosmos, even though some of them, like the Universal Soul (النفس الكلي), provide sustenance (الإمداد) by its Essence to the world of Nature without intention, just as the sun gives its light by its Essence without intending benefit or harm. This is the meaning of intrinsic (الذاتي) for it. The relation of knowledge and action is an intrinsic relation for it, due to its knowledge of itself, not of what is above it, such as its cause or other things. As for its action, the action is attributed to it, just as the whitening of cloth and the blackening of the fuller's face are attributed to the sun, and just as heating and burning are attributed to fire. So, it is said, "The sun whitened such-and-such," and "The sun revealed such-and-such," and "The fire burned such-and-such," and "It cooked such-and-such," and "It heated such-and-such." This is the state of affairs in the Cosmos, if you possess intellect and insight. And Allah <<بِكُلِّ شَيْ‏ءٍ عَلِيمٌ وعَلى‏ كُلِّ شَيْ‏ءٍ قَدِيرٌ>> (is Knower of all things and over all things Competent). For this reason, He manifests (يتجلى) in every image. The entire Cosmos emerged from non-existence (عدم) into existence (وجود), except for man alone, who appeared from existence to existence: from the existence of separation (فرق) to the existence of collection (جمع). Thus, his state changed from separation to assembly. The Cosmos's state changed from non-existence to existence. Therefore, the difference between man and the Cosmos is the difference between Existence (الوجود) and Non-existence (العدم). For this reason, nothing in the Cosmos is like man.

I am not the pure essence of Being (مخضة الوجود)
Except because I am from Being (الوجود).
No command from non-existence
Rules over my existence.
I have no equal in the Book
In tasting the delight of increase (المزيد).
For that, my being was singled out for Prostration (السجود),
And I was created for Prostration.
The command to prostrate to me encompassed all the Cosmos,
Except the one who spoke with denial (بالجحود).

When the solid dissolved, the forms changed, so the name changed, and the ruling changed. When the liquid solidified, the form changed, so the name changed, and the ruling changed. Thus, the Divine Laws (الشرائع) descended, addressing the Entities (الأعيان) according to the forms, states, and names they possess. The Entity (العين) has no address upon it from its Essence (ذاته) nor a ruling upon it from its Reality (حقيقته). For this reason, the Permissible (المباح) is among the prescribed rulings for it, while the obligatory (الواجب), the recommended (المندوب), the forbidden (المحظور), and the disliked (المكروه) are strange occurrences (الملمات الغريبة) in its existence. This is due to what is associated with it of the pure angelic spirits (الأرواح الطاهرة الملكية) and the impure satanic spirits (الشيطانية). Thus, man oscillates between three rulings: an intrinsic ruling (حكم ذاتي) that is from Him upon him, and two rulings associated with him. He has acceptance and rejection according to what the Book has preceded and the Address has decreed. <<فَمِنْهُمْ شَقِيٌّ وسَعِيدٌ>> (So among them are the wretched and the felicitous), just as among the near ones there was one brought near and one cast out. So, it is for the one who responds, and upon Allah is the clarification of error from correctness. The ultimate outcome is that Allah possesses the excellent return (حسن المآب).

Allah has never explicitly linked evil to the return (المآب) to Him. The utmost that has been reported concerning this is in the context of threat, according to the primary understanding: <<وسَيَعْلَمُ الَّذِينَ ظَلَمُوا أَيَّ مُنْقَلَبٍ يَنْقَلِبُونَ>> (And those who have wronged are going to know to what [kind of] return they will return). They will come to know of Allah's generosity (كرم الله) what <<لَمْ يَكُونُوا يَحْتَسِبُونَ>> (they had not been expecting), both before accountability for those who are forgiven, and after accountability because it ceases for them. For His Mercy (رحمته) is vast, and His Bounty (نعمته) is comprehensive and overflowing, and the souls of the Cosmos are covetous of it, because He is Generous without limitation and Absolute in Generosity (الجود) without restriction. For this reason, the Cosmos will be gathered on the Day of Resurrection <<كَالْفَراشِ الْمَبْثُوثِ>> (like scattered moths), because Mercy is spread throughout all stations. The Cosmos disperses in search of it, because the Cosmos is in different states and forms of varied aspects. Through this dispersion, they seek from Allah the Mercy that will remove from them the form that leads them to wretchedness. This is the reason for their dispersion on that Day. Likewise, the solid mountains will be <<كَالْعِهْنِ الْمَنْفُوشِ>> (like carded wool), having departed from hardness to softness, which grants mercy to the servants. No one understands what we have said except the People of Witnessing (أهل الشهود) and those realized in the Realities of Being (حقائق الوجود). As for those who remain with their two weighty natures (ثقليته), Allah only named the two weighty ones (الثقلين) by this name to distinguish them from all others, wherever they may be. Their souls continuously govern natural bodies and bodies of the world, the Isthmus (برزخ), and the Hereafter. Likewise, the stations they inhabit are of the same kind as their existence. They have no bliss except through what is suitable to their nature. As for those who advocate Abstraction (التجريد), they are correct, for the Rational Soul (النفس الناطقة) is truly abstracted from these natural bodies and forms, and its only role in them is governance (التدبير). However, they did not know that this governance for these souls is perpetual and eternal. Thus, they are correct from this perspective if they intend it, but mistaken if they say that the soul separates from governance. The Rational Souls (النفوس الناطقة), in our view, are connected by governance but separated by Essence (الذات), limit, and personal reality (الحقيقية الشخصية); thus, they are neither connected nor separated. Governance is intrinsic (ذاتي) to them, like the sun, which has intrinsic governance in what the lights of its Essence spread upon. The difference is that the sun, the moon, the stars, and most of the causes in which Allah placed benefits for the world, do not have knowledge of this for their own essences. However, the Rational Souls, even though their governance is intrinsic, are aware of what they govern. The virtuous souls among them, who possess Unveiling (الكشف), are aware of the particulars of what they govern by their Essence. The non-virtuous ones do not know the particulars of that, or they may know but not know that they know. This is the case for every governing spirit. The one who has governance over the Cosmos is the most knowledgeable of the particulars of the Cosmos, and that is Allah Almighty, the Knower of the specific part and the whole, along with the intrinsic governance that is necessarily His. The mounts of the felicitous souls are the Animal Souls (النفوس الحيوانية) in the most delightful and comfortable life on the Day of Resurrection, granted to them in that station. Similarly, they are in the most severe pain and narrowest confinement if they are wretched and imprisoned in a tight place, as He Almighty said: <<وإِذا أُلْقُوا مِنْها>> (And when they are thrown into it)—meaning Hell—<<مَكاناً ضَيِّقاً مُقَرَّنِينَ دَعَوْا هُنالِكَ ثُبُوراً>> (in a narrow place, bound in chains, they will cry out there for destruction). These states belong to the Animal Souls. The Rational Souls (النفوس الناطقة) find delight in the knowledge of the varying states of their mounts, because they are in an increase of suitable Divine knowledge (علم إلهي مناسب) through this. Do you not see a taste (ذوقا) here in two persons, each having a Rational Soul and an Animal Soul? A painful cause occurs to both persons. One is pained by it, and the other is delighted by it. This is because, although the first possesses a Rational Soul, his animality (حيوانيته) dominates him, so his Rational Soul remains inactive in its theoretical intellectual faculty. The other's Rational Soul is not inactive from its contemplation, thought, and witnessing of the source of that painful matter that arose in his Animal Soul, until it leads him to the First Cause (السبب الأول). He becomes absorbed in it, and the Animal Soul follows him in this, so the pain departs from it even while the cause remains. Both persons, as we said, possess a Rational Soul and a painful cause. Yet, the pain was lifted for one person and not for the other. The animal is illuminated by the light of the Rational Soul. If the Rational Soul directs its gaze toward the side of The Real, its light follows it, just as the light of the sun follows the sun in its setting and disappearance. The Animal Soul then finds delight in the Witnessing (الشهود) it attains, which it had not seen before. Thus, there is no pain or delight except for the Animal Souls. If it is as we described, it is an intellectual delight (لذة علمية). If it is due to the suitability of temperament, disposition, and the attainment of purpose, it is a sensory delight (لذة حسية). The Rational Soul is pure knowledge (علم مجرد) that does not admit delight or pain. A delusion and error occur to the person who has no knowledge of the matter as it is in itself, so he imagines that the Rational Soul has delight in knowledge, to the extent that they said this concerning the Divine Presence (الجناب الإلهي), claiming that He is joyful in His perfection. Look, my brother, how far removed these people are from the knowledge of the realities of things, and how excellent is

The saying of the Lawgiver: "Whoever knows himself knows his Lord."

He only attributed to Him what He attributes to Himself. Exalted is Allah Almighty far above being ruled by a state or a place. Rather, <<لِلَّهِ الْأَمْرُ من قَبْلُ ومن بَعْدُ>> (To Allah belongs the command before and after). May Allah protect us and you from afflictions and raise us to the highest degrees and furthest ends.

### The Fifteenth Connection from the Treasuries of Generosity

This is what natural bodies (الأجسام الطبيعية) store of the Lights (الأنوار) by which their being is illuminated, even if they appear dark to our eyes, just as milk comes forth <<من بَيْنِ فَرْثٍ ودَمٍ لَبَناً خالِصاً سائِغاً لِلشَّارِبِينَ>> (from between excretion and blood, pure milk, palatable to the drinkers), stored in the udders of their cattle and camels for them, just as <<شَرابٌ مُخْتَلِفٌ أَلْوانُهُ فِيهِ شِفاءٌ لِلنَّاسِ>> (a drink of varying colors, in which there is healing for people) comes forth from the bellies of bees. And Allah says: <<الله نُورُ السَّماواتِ والْأَرْضِ>> (Allah is the Light of the heavens and the earth). Were it not for the Light (النور), no entity (عين) would have appeared for the possibles (الممكنات). And the saying of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, in his supplication: "O Allah, place light in my hearing, and light in my sight, and light in my hair," until he said, "and make me light."

And it is so. He only sought the Witnessing (مشاهدة) of that so that it might appear to the eyes, for the Spiritual Light (النور المعنوي) is hidden; <<لا تُدْرِكُهُ الْأَبْصارُ>> (Vision does not perceive Him). The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, desired to perceive by sense what he had perceived by faith and intellect. This only appears to the masters of Spiritual Strivings (أرباب المجاهدات).

The fire is hidden in its stones,
It does not burn unless the flints (الأزند) strike it.

We know that there is fire, yet we do not see it heating the stone or burning the *marakh* and *afar* trees. Thus is the case for all existing things, for the one who contemplates and gains insight, or the one who witnesses and takes heed. The Real (الحق) is hidden in creation by virtue of His being Light. When the flints of creation are struck by thought (الفكر), the Light of The Real appears.

"Whoever knows himself knows his Lord."

Whoever knows the striking and distinguishes the flint, the fire is with him. Thus, he is <<عَلى‏ نُورٍ من رَبِّهِ>> (upon a light from his Lord). Whenever He wills to manifest it, He is The Manifest (الظاهر). Whenever He wills to conceal it, He is The Hidden (الباطن). When He is Hidden, <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْ‏ءٌ>> (There is nothing whatever like unto Him). When He is Manifest, <<هُوَ السَّمِيعُ الْبَصِيرُ>> (He is the All-Hearing, the All-Seeing). The striker does not bring light from himself. The Real is with us wherever we are, in non-existence or existence. By His companionship, we appeared, so we possess light, though we are unaware.

To Allah belongs what is for Allah from the entity of our being,
And to the Cosmos belongs what is for the Cosmos from the Light of His Essence (نور ذاته).
So we are many (كثير), and The Sovereign (المهيمن) is One,
He is unified in His Names (أسمائه) and Attributes (صفاته).

We said we are many and He is One because the flints (الأزند) are many, but the fire from every flint is one in essence. Whether the flint is stone or wood, the result is the same. For this reason, the sayings about Allah differ, yet the object sought is one. Everything that appears to every seeker is none other than Allah. All began from Him and return to Him. The seeker of fire in the flint is called a striker (قادح) because seeking The Real (الحق) from creation in order to know His Essence (ذاته) is a striking (قدح) against the sound knowledge of His Essence. For nothing is known of Him except the rank, which is His being a single God, exclusively. If one aims for knowledge of His Essence, which is Witnessing (المشاهدة), Witnessing only occurs through His Theophany (تجلي), and that only occurs by striking Him (بالقدح فيه). For you only see Him as restricted, restricted by your intellect through its contemplation, and He manifests to you in the form of your restriction. This is a striking against what He is in reality (في نفس الأمر). Were it not that you possess intellectual light (نور عقلي) within yourself, you would not have known Him, and were it not that you possess visual light (نور بصري), you would not have witnessed Him. You only witnessed Him by the Light, and there is no light but Him. So, you neither witnessed Him nor knew Him except by Him. He is the Light of the heavens from the perspective of the intellects, and the earth from the perspective of the eyes. Allah Almighty only made the description of His Light by the Light that is the Lamp (المصباح), which is an earthly light, not a heavenly one. He likened His Light to the Lamp, and our vision of Him is like our vision of the sun and the moon. That is, even though He is like the Lamp, He is exalted in vision and perception above the vision of the Lamp. He is intrinsically earthly, because had He not descended to us, we would not have known Him, and He is heavenly by vision. Look at how profound is the knowledge of the Lawgiver concerning Allah, and where it stands in relation to intellectual contemplation. For this reason, He said: <<لا تُدْرِكُهُ الْأَبْصارُ>> (Vision does not perceive Him), because He is Light, and Light is only perceived by Light, so He is only perceived by Him. And <<هُوَ يُدْرِكُ الْأَبْصارَ>> (He perceives [all] vision), because He is Light, and <<هُوَ اللَّطِيفُ>> (He is The Subtle), because He is subtle and hidden in the very essence of His manifestation, so He is not known or witnessed as The All-Aware (الْخَبِيرُ) knows and witnesses Himself—this is knowledge of taste (علم ذوق). And He did not say that lights do not perceive Him.

Were it not for the Light (النور), no eye would witness Him,
And were it not for the Intellect (العقل), no cosmos would know Him.

By the Cosmic Light (النور الكوني) and the Divine Light (الإلهي) was the manifestation of existing things, which have always been manifest to Him in their state of non-existence, just as they are manifest to us in their state of existence. We perceive them intellectually in their state of non-existence and perceive them visually in their state of existence. The Real perceives them visually in both states. Were it not that the possible (الممكن) in its state of non-existence possessed light within itself, it would not have accepted existence nor been distinguished from the impossible (المحال). By the light of its possibility, The Real witnessed it, and by the light of its existence, creation witnessed it. Thus, the difference between The Real and creation is the difference between the two witnessings. The Real is Light upon Light. Creation is light in darkness in its state of non-existence. As for its state of existence, it is Light upon Light, because it is the very proof of its Lord. This Connection (الوصل) cannot bear more than this, for it contains a subtle cunning (مكرا خفيا) due to the lack of a likeness (مثل) for The Real. He cannot be witnessed or known except by striking a similitude (بضرب مثل). For this reason, He made the similitude of His Light in the heavens and the earth: <<كَمِشْكاةٍ فِيها مِصْباحٌ الْمِصْباحُ في زُجاجَةٍ الزُّجاجَةُ كَأَنَّها كَوْكَبٌ دُرِّيٌّ يُوقَدُ من شَجَرَةٍ مُبارَكَةٍ زَيْتُونَةٍ لا شَرْقِيَّةٍ ولا غَرْبِيَّةٍ يَكادُ زَيْتُها يُضِي‏ءُ ولَوْ لَمْ تَمْسَسْهُ نارٌ>> (Like a niche wherein is a lamp, the lamp is in a glass, the glass as if it were a brilliant star, lit from a blessed tree, an olive tree, neither eastern nor western, whose oil would almost illuminate even if no fire touched it). Then He said: <<نُورٌ عَلى‏ نُورٍ يَهْدِي الله لِنُورِهِ>> (Light upon Light. Allah guides to His Light). From these two lights, He guides whom He wills, and <<يَضْرِبُ الله الْأَمْثالَ>> (Allah presents the similitudes). He made the striking of similitudes for the purpose of conveyance. In the striking of similitudes, the impossible (المحال) whose occurrence is not possible is permissible. Just as the impossible existence does not become existence by hypothesis, so too, creation does not become The Real by striking a similitude. What exists by hypothesis may not be valid to exist in reality. If the striking of the similitude were the very essence of the thing likened, it would only be a striking of similitude in one aspect. Therefore, what is used here for comparison and striking the similitude is not valid to exist except by hypothesis. Thus, we know by the striking of this similitude that we are at the utmost distance from Him Almighty, yet also at the utmost nearness. For this reason, we accepted the striking of the similitude, thereby combining distance and nearness. He named Himself to us as The Near (القريب) and The Distant (البعيد). Just as <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْ‏ءٌ>> (There is nothing whatever like unto Him), He is also <<أَقْرَبُ من حَبْلِ الْوَرِيدِ>> (nearer than the jugular vein), and <<هُوَ السَّمِيعُ الْبَصِيرُ>> (He is the All-Hearing, the All-Seeing). He is The Near by the similitude, The Distant by the form, because the hypothesis of a thing is not like it, nor is it the essence of the thing. In this Connection is the pouring forth of the pilgrim from Arafat to Jam' (Muzdalifah), and from Jam' to Mina. The pouring forth from Arafat is at night, and the pouring forth from Jam' is the day of the fasting person—or if you wish, you may say "day" without addition. The Pilgrimage (الحج) combines all of this, accepting the detail of the temporal day, which is night and day. Likewise, it contains what confuses the intellects from the penetration of their light to the vision of the Sought One, which is a subtle veil (حجاب لطيف) due to its nearness to the Sought One. For longing is most intense when the lover beholds the dwelling of his beloved. The poet said:

And longing is most intense one day,
When the dwellings draw near to the dwellings.

It is among the most wondrous matters that The Real (الحق) was concealed by man, so He was not witnessed, and by man He was manifested, so He was known. Thus, man combines the Veil (الحجاب) and the Manifestation (الظهور). He is the Manifesting Concealer, and he is the dull, yet sharp, sword. The Real witnesses this from him because He created him upon that, and man witnesses this from himself because he is not absent from himself. He desires connection with that which he already knows he cannot connect with. Thus, he is like The Real in His command: whoever wills Him to command him with what will not occur from him is a willer, not a willer. Were it not that The Real is the shell (صدفة) of our entities (أعياننا), we would not be the shell of the very knowledge of Him. The pearl (اللؤلؤ) is formed in the shell, and they were only formed in Being (الوجود), and Being is none other than Him. But He veiled us with a veil of preservation, then He manifested us, then He introduced Himself to us through us, and referred us back to ourselves in the knowledge of Him. When we knew Him through ourselves, we veiled our knowledge of Him. Thus, the matter never leaves the shell concealing the pearl, but sometimes one way, and sometimes the other.

That is the pure gold (التبر), and we are the echo (الصدى),
And we have no being without the Call (الندا).
Whoever calls Him becomes as if he were Him,
Yet that being did not originate from Him.
Because it comes into existence (يحدث) from His saying,
And His saying "Be" (كن) is never in vain.
From Him we were, and by Him appeared
This one who appeared in His eye.
He is the dew (الندى) by night, just as I was Him,
Just as I am from Him, a void (سدى) by day.
And if you wish the opposite of what I said,
Then He is the night, and we are the dew.

And Allah <<يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (speaks the Truth, and He guides to the Way).

### The Sixteenth Connection from the Treasuries of Generosity

Know that Allah Almighty did not create anything in the Cosmos (الكون) except that it is living and speaking (حيا ناطقا), whether it be inanimate, plant, or animal, in the higher and lower worlds. The confirmation of this is His saying: <<وإِنْ من شَيْ‏ءٍ إِلَّا يُسَبِّحُ بِحَمْدِهِ ولكِنْ لا تَفْقَهُونَ تَسْبِيحَهُمْ إِنَّهُ كانَ حَلِيماً>> (And there is nothing except that it glorifies [Allah] with His praise, but you do not understand their glorification. Indeed, He is Ever-Forbearing). He did not hasten punishment upon you. <<غَفُوراً>> (All-Forgiving), concealing their glorification from your hearing. Everything in the world of nature is a body that is nourished and sensitive, thus it is a speaking animal (حيوان ناطق), both manifest and hidden, in every single part of this definition. Whatever is lacking in it in a limited definition, that lack is what is hidden from some people, and what is manifest is the clear part. For this reason, the definitions of the inanimate, the plant, the animal, and man differ, yet all, according to the People of Unveiling (أهل الكشف), are speaking animals glorifying Allah with His praise. Since the matter is thus, it was permissible, indeed it occurred and was valid, for The Real (الحق) to address all existing things and reveal (يوحي) to them—including the heaven, the earth, mountains, trees, and other existing things—and describe them with obedience to what He commanded them and with refusal to accept His offer. Everything prostrated to Him because He manifested (تجلى) to everything and revealed to everything what He addressed that thing with. He said to the heavens and the earth: <<ائْتِيا طَوْعاً أَوْ كَرْهاً قالَتا أَتَيْنا طائِعِينَ>> (Come willingly or unwillingly. They said, "We have come willingly"). So, He <<أَوْحى‏ في كُلِّ سَماءٍ أَمْرَها>> (revealed in every heaven its command). And the earth, likewise, He revealed to it. And <<أَوْحى‏ رَبُّكَ إِلَى النَّحْلِ>> (Your Lord inspired the bee). And <<أَوْحَيْنا إِلَيْكَ>> (We revealed to you)—meaning Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, with the address—<<رُوحاً من أَمْرِنا>> (a spirit from Our command). His revelation encompassed all, but there remains the one who obeys and the one who does not obey, and how the hearing one is favored over the hearing one. It is among the most wondrous things to describe the hearing one as deaf, the seeing one as blind, and the speaking one as mute. He neither comprehended nor returned, even if he understood.

Denial (الجحد) is an attribute of the souls when they refuse,
Like fire that burns by acceptance, even if it is extinguished.
Were it not for the existence of testing (الاختبار) and their compulsion (جبرها)
within it, the souls would not refuse when they refuse.

Allah Almighty said: <<يَوْمَ تَشْهَدُ عَلَيْهِمْ أَلْسِنَتُهُمْ وأَيْدِيهِمْ وأَرْجُلُهُمْ بِما كانُوا يَعْمَلُونَ>> (The Day when their tongues, their hands, and their feet will bear witness against them as to what they used to do). For this reason, they will say to their skins when they bear witness against them: <<لِمَ شَهِدْتُمْ عَلَيْنا>> (Why have you testified against us?). And the skins will say: <<أَنْطَقَنَا الله الَّذِي أَنْطَقَ كُلَّ شَيْ‏ءٍ>> (Allah has made us speak, He who makes all things speak). Thus, it was comprehensive. The skins were more knowledgeable of the matter than those who made speech (النطق) a defining, essential characteristic (فصلا مقوما) exclusively for man, and stripped non-man of the totality of its definition in animality and speech. Whoever misses the Witnessing (الشهود) misses much knowledge. So, do not judge what you have not seen, and say, "Allah knows best what He created." The earth of man is his body, and it has borne witness against him concerning what he did. Do you think it bore witness against him concerning what it did not know? Do you think it knew without Divine Revelation (وحي إلهي) coming to it from Allah Almighty, just as we bear witness against the nations concerning what Allah Almighty revealed to us of the stories of His prophets with their nations?

The person bears witness to what he did not see
If the truthful report (الخبر الصادق) comes to him.
For all have been inspired by the One who
Inspired by Him, so all are speaking (ناطق).
Look, for there is none in His Being (كونه) other than Him,
So He is the Existence (وجود) of the creation and the Creator.

When the matter is confined between a truthful report (خبر صادق) and Witnessing (شهود), we know that the entire Cosmos is unveiled to Him.

There is no veil (ستر) or barrier (حجاب) there,
Rather, all of it is manifest and clear.
So The Real knows without doubt,
And His secret is buried in the depths.

He reveals by the command "Be" (التكوين), and it is. He witnesses what He wills, and it is seen. His Witnessing by the truthful report is like His Witnessing by direct sight (العيان) in which there is no doubt.

An example is the testimony of Khuzaymah, whom the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, placed in his testimony in the position of two men, so he judged by his testimony alone.

Thus, testimony by Revelation (الوحي) was more perfect than testimony by sight (العين), because if Khuzaymah had testified by sight, his testimony would not have been equivalent to two. By this, Allah preserved for us <<لَقَدْ جاءَكُمْ رَسُولٌ من أَنْفُسِكُمْ>> (There has certainly come to you a Messenger from among yourselves) until the end of the Sura, since the compiler of the Quran did not accept any verse of it except with the testimony of two men or more, except for this verse, <<لَقَدْ جاءَكُمْ رَسُولٌ من أَنْفُسِكُمْ>>, which was established by the testimony of Khuzaymah alone, may Allah be pleased with him.

### Connection and Alert

As for speaking about Gnostic Matters (الأمور الذوقية), it is valid, but not for the purpose of intellectual comprehension. Rather, every tasted experience (مذوق) has a similitude (مثال مضروب) struck for it, so you understand from it only what is suitable to that specific similitude. Therefore, nothing conveys the reality except in the shared taste (الذوق المشترك) upon which convention can be established, like speaking about sensory matters with every possessor of sense who perceived the reported matter with his sense and knew the word that denotes it by agreement among the addressed parties. We do not doubt, when the Quran is recited to us, that we have heard the Speech of Allah (كلام الله). And Moses, peace be upon him, when Allah spoke to him, heard the Speech of Allah. Yet, where is Moses compared to us in this hearing? Gnostic reports occur in a similar manner. The perception attained by one who hears the Speech of Allah within himself, directly from Allah, without intermediaries (الوسائط), cannot be equal in perception to one who hears it through translation. The one who possesses the intermediary is given the choice to report it on behalf of the intermediary if he wishes, or on behalf of the Speaker if he wishes. This is how it came in the Quran. He Almighty said, attributing the speech to Himself: <<فَأَجِرْهُ حَتَّى يَسْمَعَ كَلامَ الله>> (Then grant him protection until he hears the Speech of Allah). He attributed the speech to Allah. And He spoke, attributing that speech to the intermediary and translator, swearing: <<إِنَّهُ>> (Indeed, it)—meaning the Quran—<<لَقَوْلُ رَسُولٍ كَرِيمٍ ذِي قُوَّةٍ عِنْدَ ذِي الْعَرْشِ مَكِينٍ>> (is the word of a noble Messenger, possessing power, secure with the Possessor of the Throne). And He said: <<إِنَّهُ لَقَوْلُ رَسُولٍ كَرِيمٍ وما هُوَ بِقَوْلِ شاعِرٍ>> (Indeed, it is the word of a noble Messenger, and it is not the word of a poet). If you understand from the Divine what this address contains, you will attain sublime knowledge. Likewise, <<ما يَأْتِيهِمْ من ذِكْرٍ من رَبِّهِمْ مُحْدَثٍ>> (No reminder comes to them from their Lord that is newly produced). He attributed the newness (الحدوث) to His Speech. Whoever distinguishes between the Speech and the Speaker (as the object of the verb) has attained some knowledge. The All-Merciful only made His Speech heard by removing the intermediaries so that longing (الاشتياق) for the vision of the Speaker might be established in the hearer, due to the beauty of the Speech he heard. Thus, the desire for the vision of the Speaker becomes more intense, especially since the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, Allah is Beautiful and loves beauty."

Beauty (الجمال) is loved for its own sake, and The Real (الحق) has described Himself with it, thus creating longing in the souls for His vision. As for the intellects (العقول), some stand in a position of confusion and do not judge, while others definitively rule that vision is impossible due to the conventional restriction (التقييد العادي) inherent in sight. They imagine that this restriction in visual perception is a natural, intrinsic matter for the eyes, and this is due to the lack of taste (عدم الذوق). Perhaps some believers among them strengthen the ruling of impossibility by His saying: <<لا تُدْرِكُهُ الْأَبْصارُ>> (Vision does not perceive Him). Eyes have perception, and insights (البصائر) have perception, and both are originated (محدث). If it is valid to perceive Him by the intellect, which is originated, then it is valid or permissible to perceive Him by sight, because one originated thing has no superiority over another originated thing in terms of origination, even if the predispositions (الاستعدادات) differ. It is permissible for every recipient of predispositions to accept the predisposition of the one who accepted that he perceived The Real by his intellectual contemplation. They must either negate this entirely, or permit it entirely, or stand still in judgment, neither ruling it impossible nor permissible until a definition from The Real comes to them explicitly, about which they have no doubt, or until they witness Him from their own souls. As for the one who claims that he perceives Him intellectually but not visually, he is a trifler (متلاعب) who has no knowledge of the intellect, nor of sight, nor of realities as they are in themselves, like the Mu'tazilite (المعتزلي), for this is his rank. One who does not distinguish between conventional and natural matters should not be spoken to concerning any of the sciences, especially the sciences of Gnostic Tastes (علوم الأذواق). Allah did not create longing in His servants for His vision through His Speech in vain. Were it not that Moses, peace be upon him, understood from the matter—when Allah spoke to him without intermediaries—what emboldened him to ask for the Vision, he would not have done so. For hearing the Speech of Allah Almighty without intermediaries is the very essence of understanding from Him, and thus does not require interpretation or contemplation. Only the one to whom Allah spoke through intermediaries, such as a Messenger or a Book, requires that. Since the very essence of hearing in this station is the very essence of understanding, he asked for the Vision so that the follower and the one who does not possess this rank with Allah might know that the vision of Allah is not impossible. Allah testified that He chose Moses above mankind by His messages and by His speech, and then said to him: <<فَخُذْ ما آتَيْتُكَ وكُنْ من الشَّاكِرِينَ>> (So take what I have given you and be among the grateful). And He Almighty says: <<لَئِنْ شَكَرْتُمْ لَأَزِيدَنَّكُمْ>> (If you are grateful, I will surely increase you). There is no doubt that Moses thanked Allah for the blessing of being chosen and the blessing of speech, a necessary and commanded gratitude. Thus, Allah would increase him for his gratitude with the blessing of seeing Him. Did he see Him at the time of his request, according to the condition He established for him, as stated in the text of the Quran, or did he not see Him? The verse is open to interpretation, for He did not negate the present time from the attachment of vision; rather, He negated the future by the particle *sawfa* (سوف). There is no doubt that Allah manifested (تجلى) to the mountain, which is originated, and the mountain crumbled (تدكدك) due to His manifestation. From this, we derive the mountain's vision of its Lord, which necessitated its crumbling. Thus, an originated thing saw Him. What prevents Moses, peace be upon him, from having seen Him during the state of crumbling, with the negation applying to the future? There is no impediment to this for the rational person, especially since the swoon (الصعق) that befell Moses, peace be upon him, took the place of the mountain's crumbling. Furthermore, know that whoever perceives The Real by knowledge (علما) does not miss a single issue of Divine Knowledge. And whoever sees The Real with his sight (ببصره) sees every type of the Cosmos, missing nothing of its types, provided he sees Him without matter (في غير مادة). If he knows Him by an attribute of intrinsic affirmation, he attains this station. But if he knows Him by an attribute of Transcendence (تنزيه), he does not attain this station. And if he sees Him in matter, he does not attain this station. As for the one who holds that the vision of The Real is merely an expression of increased clarity in theoretical knowledge of Allah and nothing else, this is the saying of one who has no knowledge of Allah through the path of Unveiling (الكشف) and Theophany (التجلي), unless he said that for a meaning that was present, which should not be heard by others. And Allah <<يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (speaks the Truth, and He guides to the Way).

### The Seventeenth Connection from the Treasuries of Generosity

Some masters concerning this treasury have said that it encompasses the annihilation (فناء) of that which never was and the subsistence (بقاء) of that which never ceases to be. This issue has caused confusion for those whose unveiling (كشف) is not firm and whose witnessing (شهود) is not realized. For among people are those to whom a flash of their desired object appears, and they are satisfied with it, neglecting the full realization and exhaustive study of the spiritual state. They then pass judgment on this station based on what they witnessed of it, believing, either conjecturally or definitively, that they have fully encompassed it.

I have seen men of this description. Such a thing occurred to Sahl ibn Abd Allah al-Tustari, who was prominent in this field concerning the science of the Isthmus (البرزخ). A glimpse passed over him, and he encompassed knowledge of the state of people in the Barzakh. He did not pause to see whether what he saw would undergo alteration in different states for its inhabitants, or whether they would persist in a single state. Thus, he judged that they would remain in a single state, just as he saw them. His vision was sound and truthful, but his judgment regarding the permanence of their state until the Day of Resurrection is not sound.

As for those of this description whom I have seen, when I observed their swift return and lack of firmness when taken away from their self, I asked one of them, "What causes you to return so quickly?" He replied, "I fear that my essence (عيني) will be annihilated by what we witness." Thus, he fears for his self. Whoever is in this state will not have a firm footing in the realization of any matter, nor will he be among those firmly rooted (الراسخين) in it. If they had confined themselves to what they directly perceived and refrained from passing judgment, it would have been better for them.

An outsider, hearing such a thing from a truthful person, and hearing of the lack of permanence in the Barzakh in a single state, might imagine that there is a disagreement among the people [of God] regarding this matter. But it is not a disagreement. For the firmly rooted (الراسخ) speaks according to what he witnessed, which is the extent of his knowledge (العلم). The one who is not firmly rooted also speaks according to what he witnessed, but adds the judgment of permanence to which he inclined. If he had remained a little longer, he would have seen change and alteration in the Barzakh, just as it is in the World (الدنيا).

For Allah is in a state (شأن) every day—and that is the singular moment (الزمن الفرد)—as the Exalted says: <<يَسْئَلُهُ من في السَّماواتِ والْأَرْضِ كُلَّ يَوْمٍ هُوَ في شَأْنٍ>> (Everyone in the heavens and the earth asks Him. Every day He is in a [new] state). And Creation (الخلق) is new, whether it be the world, the afterlife, or the Barzakh. It is therefore impossible for a state to remain upon the essence (عين) of two moments or two times, due to the Divine Vastness (الاتساع الإلهي) and the perpetual need (الافتقار) of the World (العالم) for Allah. Change is thus necessary for it in every moment, and Allah is the Creator within it in every moment. Thus, states are renewed with the breaths (الأنفاس) upon the essences (الأعيان). The ruling of the essences dictates, concerning the single essence, according to its realities (حقائقها), that if its existence (وجودها) were sound, it would possess these states.

Some of our companions hold that the very Essence of Existence (عين الوجود) is what preserves the states of the Fixed Entities (الأعيان الثابتة) of the contingent things (الممكنات), and that these entities have no existence (وجود) whatsoever, but rather they possess fixity (الثبوت) and ruling (الحكم) within the manifest Essence, which is the Real Existence (الوجود الحقيقي). Others of our companions hold that the essences are characterized by existence, which they derive from the Exalted Real (الحق تعالى), and that they are one in substance (الجوهر) even if they multiply, and that the Real clothes them with states alongside the breaths, for they have no subsistence (بقاء) except through them. Thus, the Real renews them upon the essences in every time.

According to the first view, the saying [of the masters] means: until that which never was is annihilated (يفنى من لم يكن), so that no trace (أثر) of it remains in the Essence of Existence, and it is stripped of attributes (مسلوب النعوت). That is the state of Transcendence (التنزيه). And that which never ceases to be (من لم يزل) subsists upon the state of its Essence, which is the One independent of the worlds (الغني عن العالمين). For the World is nothing but contingent things, and He, the Exalted, is independent of them, even if they point to Him, for there is none who seeks evidence for Him based on what we have stated. For the contingent things, in their Fixed Entities, are witnessed by the Real, and the Real is witnessed by the essences of the contingent things through their fixed essence and fixed sight, not their existent one. Thus, He witnesses them as fixity (ثبوتا), and they witness Him as existence (وجودا).

According to the other view, which holds the existence of the essences of contingent things and the traces (آثار) of the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية) within them, and the Real's sustenance (إمداد) of them with those traces for their subsistence: Those traces and the essences that receive them are annihilated (تفني) from the person experiencing this witnessing (الشهود) as a spiritual state (حالا). The matter itself remains existent as it is; it is not annihilated in itself, as it is annihilated for the one who asserts this. Thus, nothing remains witnessed by him except the Exalted Allah. The existent things (الموجودات) are subsumed into the Existence of the Real (وجود الحق) and vanish from the sight of the possessor of this station, just as the essences of the stars vanish from the observer upon the rising of the Greatest Luminary, which is the sun. So he asserts the annihilation (فناء) of their essences from existence, yet they are not annihilated in reality (نفس الأمر); rather, they remain in their state of contingency (إمكانها) within their sphere, according to their ruling and movement. Both sayings are known among the Sufi community.

Some of the possessors of this station make the matter of Creation (الخلق) with the Real (الحق) like the moon with the sun regarding the light that appears on the moon. The moon has no light from its own essence (ذاته), nor is the sun or its light within it, but the sight perceives it thus. The light in the moon is none other than the sun; likewise, the existence (الوجود) belonging to the contingent things is none other than the Existence of the Real, like an image in a mirror. The sun is not *in* the moon, and that light spread at night from the moon upon the earth, when the sun's light is absent, is none other than the sun's light, yet it is attributed to the moon, just as it is said concerning the Word of Allah: <<إِنَّهُ لَقَوْلُ رَسُولٍ كَرِيمٍ>> (Indeed, it is the word of a noble messenger), and it is said concerning the saying of the Messenger (peace and blessings be upon him) that it is the Word of the Exalted Allah when he recites it, and [it is] the saying of every reciter of the Quran. For every assertion, there is an aspect of soundness and unveiling (الكشف) present in everything we have mentioned. Thus, the disagreement among the People of Allah (أهل الله) is an agreement, because they shoot from a single bow.

The matter oscillates between the annihilation of the essence (فناء عين) and the annihilation of the state (فناء حال). There is no one in the World who combines the two opposites except the People of Allah exclusively. This is because that by which they are realized is the Combiner of the two opposites, and by Him the Gnostics (العارفون) know. He is the First and the Last, the Manifest and the Hidden, from a single essence (عين واحدة) and a single relationship (نسبة واحدة), not from two different relationships. Thus, they departed from the rationally conceivable, and intellects (العقول) did not restrict them. Rather, they are the realized Divine Ones (الإلهيون المحققون). The Real realized them through what He made them witness, so they are, and they are not. <<وما رَمَيْتَ إِذْ رَمَيْتَ ولكِنَّ الله رَمى‏>> (And you did not throw when you threw, but Allah threw). Thus, He affirmed and negated. Allah is sufficient for us, and He suffices.

Shaykh Abu al-Abbas ibn al-Arif al-Sanhaji, the Imam in this field, used to say: "The Real (الحق) only becomes manifest upon the disappearance of the trace (الرسم)." And Shaykh Abu Madyan used to say: "The trace of servitude (رسم العبودية) must remain so that the delight of witnessing Lordship (الربوبية) may occur." And Al-Qasim ibn al-Qasim, one of the masters of Al-Qushayri's Risala, used to say: "The witnessing of the Real is annihilation (فناء) in which there is no delight." Every speaker is truthful.

### [That the Real does not repeat the Theophany (التجلي) to a person in a single form]

We have previously established in this book that two persons never unite in a single theophany (تجلي), and that the Real does not repeat the theophany to a person in a single form. We have also established that His theophanies differ because they encompass the intellectual (المعنوية), spiritual (الروحانية), angelic (الملكية), natural (الطبيعية), and elemental (العنصرية) forms. He appears in whatever form He wills, just as <<فِي أَيِّ صُورَةٍ ما شاءَ رَكَّبَكَ>> (In whatever form He willed, He assembled you). And on the Path, He establishes you in whatever form He wills. The mounts are different, but the rider is one.

Whoever receives a theophany in the intellectual forms asserts the annihilation of the trace (فناء الرسم). Whoever receives a theophany in the natural and elemental forms asserts delight in the witnessing (المشاهدة). And whoever asserts the absence of delight in the witnessing, the theophany was for him in the spiritual forms. All spoke truthfully, and they spoke according to what they witnessed. As for which witnessing is higher, we entrust that to your taste (ذوقك), so that you may know from it what we have known.

From this section, you learn about the separate and the non-separate, who distinguishes and who does not distinguish. You learn from it who is <<عَلى‏ بَيِّنَةٍ من رَبِّهِ>> (upon clear evidence from his Lord), and what that evidence is. You learn the types of purifications for everyone described by purity, and you learn the praiseworthy inclination and the blameworthy inclination. You learn what constitutes commonality in religion and what has been abrogated from it, such that two messengers did not agree upon it. You learn which creatures were created from an existent thing and which were created from no existent thing, and the levels of the World (العالم) in that regard. You learn that everything the Real requested His servants to treat Him with, He treated them with, thus encompassing all the rulings of the Divine Laws (الشرائع) and judging Himself by them just as He judged His Creation. And that the noble moral qualities (مكارم الأخلاق) in the cosmos (الأكوان) are the Divine Moral Qualities (الأخلاق الإلهية).

### "The Eighteenth Section" from the Treasuries of Generosity (خزائن الجود)

It contains the excellence (فضل) of Nature (الطبيعة) over others, due to its resemblance to the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية). For the wonder is not in an existent thing that produces an effect, but rather the wonder is in a non-existent thing that produces an effect. And all relationships (النسب) are non-existent matters (أمور عدمية), yet they possess effect and ruling.

Everything whose essence (العين) is non-existent but whose ruling and effect are manifest is, in reality, what is expressed as the Unseen (الغيب), for that which is absent in its essence is the Unseen. Nature is absent in essence from Existence (الوجود), so it has no essence therein, and [absent] from fixity (الثبوت), so it has no essence therein. Thus, it is the realized World of the Unseen (عالم الغيب المحقق). It is known, just as the impossible is known. However, Nature, although it is like the impossible in having fixity and existence negated from it, still has an effect, and forms appear from it, which is not the case for the impossible.

The keys to this Unseen are the Divine Names, which none knows except Allah, the Knower of all things. The Divine Names are unseen relationships (نسب غيبية), for the key to the Unseen can only be the Unseen. These Names are understood to be numerous, differing realities whose difference is known, and they are attributed only to the Real (الحق), for He is their Named One, and He does not multiply through them. If they were existent matters subsisting in Him, He would multiply through them. He, the Glorified, knows them by virtue of being the Knower of every known thing, and we know them through the difference of the traces (الآثار) from them within us. So we named Him thus based on the trace found in us. The traces multiplied in us, so the Names multiplied, and the Real is their Named One. They were attributed to Him, but He did not multiply in Himself through them. Thus, we knew that they are absent in essence (غائبة العين).

When Allah opened the world of natural bodies (عالم الأجسام الطبيعية) through their combination, after they had been separate in the Unseen, known to be separate in Knowledge (العلم)—for if they had been combined by their own essence, the existence of the world of bodies would have been eternal (أزلا) by itself, not by Allah. There is no existent thing that is not Allah except that it is *from* Allah. There is no Necessary Existent (واجب الوجود) by His Essence except Allah. Everything other than Him exists *by* Him, not by its own essence. The secret is the rationally conceivable relationships, otherwise their essences would be hidden from them. By the Will (المشيئة), the effect of Nature—which is Unseen—appeared. Thus, the Will is the key to that Unseen. And the Will is a Divine relationship (نسبة إلهية) that has no essence, so the key is Unseen. Even if these relationships are not fixed in Knowledge, and even though they are Unseen and non-existent (عدما), existence for any existent thing would not be sound at all, nor would there be Creation (خلق) or the Real (حق). Thus, they are indispensable.

The Unseen (الغيب) is the general, radiant Light (النور الساطع العام) by which all Existence (الوجود) appeared. That which has no manifestation in its essence is the General Treasury (الخزانة العامة), and its keeper is from it.

If you wish to make the conception of what I have said easier for you, look at the essential definitions (الحدود الذاتية) of the defined thing (المحدود), by which the defined thing is only rationally conceived, and by the absence of which the known thing is annihilated, and by the existence of which it is known expansively, even if they are not described by existence. This is, for example, when you take the definition of substance (الجوهر), meaning the individual substance (الجوهر الفرد). You say concerning it: "It is the thing (الشيء)." You have thus brought the most general genus. The thing-ness (الشيئية) of things is not existent, yet it is indispensable. It includes everything defined by a thing, whether it subsists by itself or does not subsist by itself. If you wish to clarify it—and known things are only clarified by their essence, which is their essential definition (الحد الذاتي)—you say: "The existent (الموجود)." You have thus brought something more specific than the genus. Every existent thing enters into it, and everything that has thing-ness but no existence is separated from it. Then you say: "That which subsists by itself (القائم بنفسه)." All of these are known meanings (معان معلومة) which are attributes (صفات) for the defined thing known by them, and an attribute does not subsist by itself. By the combination of these meanings, existent essences (أعيان وجودية) arise from them, which are perceived sensually and intellectually. Every existent thing that does not subsist by itself is excluded from this. Then you say: "The spatially delimited (المتحيز)." Others share this with it, and another thing is distinguished from it by this. Spatial delimitation (التحيز) is a ruling, which is that which has measure in space or is receptive to place. Then you say: "The individual (الفرد) whose essence does not divide." The body (الجسم) and everything that divides is excluded from it. Then you say: "The receptive to accidents (الأعراض)." That which does not accept accidents is excluded from it, and that which accepts accidents enters into the definition with it. By the totality of these meanings, the named thing became the individual substance, just as by composition with the rest of the definitions, the body appeared.

When forms subsisting by themselves appeared from the harmony of meanings, and [forms] seeking loci in which to subsist, such as accidents and attributes, we knew definitively that everything other than the Real (الحق) is a vanishing accident (عرض زائل) and a manifest purpose (غرض ماثل). And that even if it is characterized by existence (الوجود), being in this state in itself, it is in the ruling of the non-existent (المعدوم). Thus, there must be a Preserver (حافظ) who preserves existence upon it, and that is none other than the Exalted Allah. If the World—meaning its existence—were due to the Essence of the Real (ذات الحق) and not due to the relationships (النسب), the World would be co-eternal with the Real in existence, which is not the case. The relationships are a ruling belonging to Allah eternally (أزلا), and they necessitate the posteriority of the World's existence to the Real's Existence, thus validating the createdness (حدوث) of the World. This is only due to the relationship of the Will (المشيئة) and the precedence of Knowledge (العلم) concerning its existence. Thus, the existence of the World was preferred (مرجحا) over its non-existence. The preferred existence does not co-exist with the Essential Existence (الوجود الذاتي) which is not characterized by preference.

Since the manifestation of the World in its essence is the totality of these meanings, this rationally conceived, defined thing (المحدود) was presented with all these meanings, and thus appeared. What it is in itself is nothing other than the totality of these meanings. And the meanings are renewed upon it, and Allah is the Preserver of its existence by renewing them upon it, and they are the very self of the defined thing. All defined things are in a new creation (خلق جديد), concerning which people are in confusion. Allah is the Creator perpetually, and the World is in perpetual need of Him for the preservation of its existence through its renewal. The World is rationally conceived by its essence, but existent by the Exalted Allah. Its essential definitions (حدوده النفسية) are its essence (عينه).

This is what led the Ash'arites (الحسبانية) to assert the perpetual renewal of the essences of the World in every singular moment (زمان فرد). But they overlooked the rational conceivability of the World insofar as it is defined, which is an imaginary matter (أمر وهمي) that has no existence except through imagination (الوهم), and which is the recipient of these meanings. And in Knowledge (العلم) there is that which is other than the totality of these meanings. Thus, a matter which is in itself a totality of rationally conceived things (معقولات) became sensually perceived. Its conception became difficult and hard for one whose imagination dominates him, so he is perplexed between his knowledge and his imagination, and this is a place of bewilderment.

One group asserted the renewal of accidents (الأعراض) upon the substance (الجوهر), and that the substance is fixed in existence, even though it has no subsistence except through the accident. The proponent of this view did not realize what he was denying. Something was hidden from him, so he was ignorant of it, and something appeared to him, so he knew it. Another group asserted the renewal of some accidents, which they call accidents, while others—even though they are truly accidents according to what Knowledge dictates—they call necessary attributes (صفات لازمة), such as the yellowness of gold or the blackness of the Ethiopian. All of this applies to those who affirm them as existent essences (أعيانا وجودية). Then there are those who say that all of that is merely relationships (نسب) that have no existence except in the essence of the one who perceives them, and no existence in their own essence. This is the view attributed to Qadi Abu Bakr ibn al-Tayyib al-Baqillani, according to what has reached us, and the responsibility rests with the transmitter.

The People of Unveiling (أهل الكشف) have a comprehensive insight into all doctrines (المذاهب), sects (النحل), religions (الملل), and assertions concerning Allah, such that they are ignorant of nothing of it. No sect appears from an adherent, nor a religion with a specific law upon which it stands, nor an assertion concerning Allah or any cosmos (كون) among the cosmoses—whether contradictory, differing, or similar—but that the possessor of unveiling knows where this assertion, religion, or sect was derived from. He attributes it to its source, offers an excuse for the one who asserts it, does not declare him mistaken, and does not deem his saying futile. For Allah did not create the heavens, the earth, or what is between them in vain, nor did He create humanity aimlessly. Rather, He created him to be alone upon His Form.

Everyone in the World is ignorant of the whole and knowledgeable of the part, except the Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل) alone, for Allah taught him all the Names (الأسماء كلها) and gave him the comprehensive words (جوامع الكلم). Thus, his form was perfected, combining the Form of the Real and the form of the World. He was thus an Isthmus (برزخ) between the Real and the World, a mirror set up in which the Real sees His Form in the mirror of the Human, and Creation also sees its form in him. Whoever attains this level has attained the rank of perfection (الكمال) than which there is none more perfect in contingency (الإمكان).

The meaning of seeing the Form of the Real in him is the application of all the Divine Names to him, as came in the tradition: "By them you are granted victory, and Allah is the Granter of Victory. By them you are provided sustenance, and Allah is the Provider. By them you are shown mercy, and Allah is the Merciful." It has been mentioned in the Quran concerning one whose perfection we know and believe in: <<بِالْمُؤْمِنِينَ رَؤُفٌ رَحِيمٌ>> (To the believers, [he is] kind and merciful). And <<وما أَرْسَلْناكَ إِلَّا رَحْمَةً لِلْعالَمِينَ>> (And We did not send you except as a mercy to the worlds)—meaning, so that you may show them mercy, when he prayed against [the tribes of] Ri'l, Dhakwan, and Usayya.

All scholars affirm the assumption of the Divine Moral Qualities (التخلق بالأسماء). Thus, the human is characterized and named as the Living, the Knowing, the Willing, the Hearing, the Seeing, the Speaking, the Powerful. And all the Divine Names, whether Names of Transcendence (تنزيه) or Names of Acts (أفعال), are under the encompassment of these seven Names we mentioned; not a single one falls outside of them. For this reason, we have not detailed them here. We have mentioned a sufficient portion of them in our book entitled *Insha' al-Jadawil wa al-Dawa'ir* (The Creation of Tables and Circles), in which we depicted the World and the Two Presences (الحضرتين) represented in forms, so that knowledge of them may be made accessible to the possessor of imagination (الخيال). For the human, along with his intellect (عقله), is not free from the ruling of imagination (الوهم) concerning what he knows to be impossible, yet he conceives it, and the ruling of imagination dominates him, since knowledge of it cannot be regulated except after its conception. At that point, the retentive faculty (القوة الحافظة) controls it, and the recollective faculty (القوة المذكرة) rules over it if it overcomes the retentive faculty and escapes its control. For the recollective faculty does not let go of it, so the known thing remains confined within Knowledge. For this reason, the known thing is encompassed, as the Exalted says: <<أَحاطَ بِكُلِّ شَيْ‏ءٍ عِلْماً>> (He encompasses all things in [His] Knowledge).

Whoever knows what we have mentioned in this section and what this treasury contains, knows his self, knows his Lord, and knows the World and its origin. And when whatever appears from it appears to him, he knows whence he came and whither he returns, and he knows what is due to him from it, so he fulfills its due, giving every possessor of a right his right, just as Allah gave every thing its creation. That which the Real is unique in possessing is Creation (الخلق), and that which the Perfect One among the World is unique in possessing is the Real. Thus, he knows what every existent thing deserves and gives it its due, and this is called fairness (الإنصاف). If you give it its due, you have been fair to it. If you exaggerate (تغاليت), you are not perfect, and you are deficient, for excess in the definition (الحد) is deficiency in the defined thing (المحدود). The Perfect One does not transgress the rank of a thing. Allah the Exalted censured, as a lesson for us in establishing justice in things, those who exaggerate in their religion and declare the Exalted Real transcendent beyond what He deserves. Even if he intended glorification by that act of exaggeration, he fell into ignorance and brought deficiency into the place of perfection. So He said: <<لا تَغْلُوا في دِينِكُمْ ولا تَقُولُوا عَلَى الله إِلَّا الْحَقَّ>> (Do not exaggerate in your religion, nor say about Allah except the truth).

Exaggeration is, for example, attributing spiritual states (الأحوال) to Allah, when they are nothing but the rulings of meanings (أحكام المعاني). The meanings belong to Allah in their existence. When they are found in the one in whom they are found, they inherently give the state (الحال) by which that locus (المحل) where this meaning subsists is described. This is an example of exaggeration. This is like the knowing, the powerful, the white, the black, the brave, the cowardly, the moving, and the still. These are the states, and they are the rulings of the rationally conceived meanings (المعاني المعقولة) or relationships (النسب)—say what you will. These meanings are Knowledge (العلم), Power (القدرة), whiteness, blackness, bravery, cowardice, movement, and stillness. So He said to us: <<لا تَقُولُوا عَلَى الله إِلَّا الْحَقَّ>> (Nor say about Allah except the truth). This was the case when they attributed a consort (الصاحبة) and a son (الولد) to the Exalted, struck similitudes for Him, and set up rivals (أندادا) for Him, exaggerating in their religion and glorifying their messengers. They said Jesus is Allah, and one group said he is the Son of Allah. And he who did not exaggerate in his religion said: He is the servant of Allah, and <<كَلِمَتُهُ أَلْقاها إِلى‏ مَرْيَمَ ورُوحٌ مِنْهُ>> (His Word which He directed to Mary, and a Spirit from Him). He did not transgress the reality of the matter. Whoever follows our path has followed the path of salvation and faith (الايمان), and has given faith its due, without letting intellect (العقل) or thought (الفكر) run loose concerning the Real or what belongs to Him. <<والله يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the Truth, and He guides to the Way).

Among the sciences in this treasury is the knowledge of the station of all the angels, the knowledge of the Lights (الأنوار) and the Secrets (الأسرار), and temporal excellence (الفضل الزماني), not excellence *by* time. From here, the angels descend upon the hearts of the Messengers among humanity with the prescribed Revelation (الوحي المشروع), and upon the hearts of the Saints (الأولياء) with inner discourse (الحديث) and inspiration (الإلهام). Everyone who perceives this secretly or as the Unseen, such that it becomes manifest and witnessed for him, [it comes] from this treasury. Glory be to the Arranger of affairs, the Expander of breasts, and the Resurrector of those in the graves with the revival. There is no god but He, the All-Knowing, the All-Powerful.

### "The Nineteenth Section" from the Treasuries of Generosity (خزائن الجود)

This is the treasury of teaching, the elevation of the teacher over the student, and the necessary etiquette (الأدب) required of the student toward his master.

### [That the Teacher in Reality is the Exalted Allah]

Know that the Teacher in reality is the Exalted Allah. The entire World (العالم) is a beneficiary, a seeker, one in need, possessing a necessity, and this is its perfection. Whoever does not possess these descriptions is ignorant of his self. Whoever is ignorant of his self is ignorant of his Lord. Whoever is ignorant of a matter has not given it its due. And whoever does not give a matter its due has acted unjustly toward it in judgment and is devoid of the attainment of Knowledge. It has thus become clear to you that all nobility (الشرف) lies only in Knowledge (العلم) and in the one who knows by virtue of that Knowledge. If he is given an action concerning the side of the Real, he performs it; and if he is given an action concerning the side of Creation, he performs it. He walks upon a pure, clear, and generous path, in which <<لا يرى فِيها عِوَجاً ولا أَمْتاً>> (he sees no deviation or unevenness).

The first learner before Knowledge, by learning, not by Essence (الذات), was the First Intellect (العقل الأول). It understood from Allah what He taught it, and He commanded it to write what He taught it upon the Preserved Tablet (اللوح المحفوظ), which He created from it, and He named it the Pen (قلما). Part of the knowledge He taught it was that, out of etiquette (أدبا) toward the Teacher, it said to Him: "What shall I write? What You have taught me, or what You dictate to me?" This is the etiquette of the student when the teacher gives him a general statement and he seeks detail. He said to it: "Write what was, what you have already known, and what will be, from what I dictate to you, which is My Knowledge concerning My Creation until the Day of Resurrection, and nothing else." So it wrote what was in its knowledge of what was. It wrote the Cloud ('Ama') in which the Real was before He created His Creation, and the realities (الحقائق) that Cloud contains—which we have mentioned in this book in the chapter on the Soul (Nafs). It wrote the existence of the bewildered Spirits (الأرواح المهيمة), what bewildered them, their states, and what they are upon—all of this so that He might teach it. It wrote the effect of His Names (أسمائه) upon them. It wrote its own self, its existence, the form of its existence, and the sciences it contains. And it wrote the Tablet (اللوح).

When it finished all of this, the Real dictated to it what will be from it until the Day of Resurrection, because the entry of the infinite (ما لا يتناهى) into existence is impossible, so it is not written, for writing is an existent matter (أمر وجودي) and must necessarily be finite. The Exalted Real dictated to it, and the Pen wrote with its head bowed, out of etiquette toward the Teacher, because dictation has no connection to sight. Rather, sight is connected to the thing being written upon, while the hearing of the Pen is connected to what the Real dictates to it. The reality of hearing (السمع) is that the heard thing is not restricted to a specific direction, unlike physical sight (البصر الحسي), which is restricted either to a specific direction or to all directions. Hearing is not like that. For its object is speech. If the speaker has a direction or is in a direction, that refers back to him. If he is neither in a direction nor has a direction, that refers back to Him, not to the hearer. Thus, hearing is more indicative of Transcendence (التنزيه) than sight, further removed from restriction, and broader and clearer in absolute freedom (الإطلاق).

The first master (أستاذ) from the World is the First Intellect (العقل الأول), and the first student who took from a created master is the Preserved Tablet (اللوح المحفوظ). This naming is based on Divine Law (شرعية). The name of the Preserved Tablet among the rationalists (العقلاء) is the Universal Soul (النفس الكلية). It is the first emanated existent thing, passive to the Intellect. It is to the Intellect as Eve was to Adam: created from him and paired with him. Thus, existence was doubled by the created thing, and knowledge was doubled by the created Pen.

Then Allah ordered Creation (الخلق) by bringing it into existence until the turn and the Divine ordering reached the manifestation of this Adamic human existence (النشأة الإنسانية الآدمية). He originated it <<فِي أَحْسَنِ تَقْوِيمٍ>> (in the best of stature). Then He breathed into Adam from His Spirit and commanded the angels to prostrate to him. They fell prostrate to him by that Divine command, making him a *qibla* for His angels. Then He informed them of his vicegerency (خلافته) on earth. They did not know whose vicegerent he was, and perhaps they thought he was a vicegerent for those who preceded him in its cultivation. So they objected when they saw the opposition of his natures in his creation, knowing that haste would rush upon him, and that the opposition of the elements from which his body was composed would result in conflict, leading to corruption on earth and the shedding of blood.

When He informed them that He, the Glorified, created him upon His Form, and taught him all the Names (الأسماء كلها) directed toward the creation of the elemental world and what is above it, He then presented the named things to the angels and said: <<أَنْبِئُونِي بِأَسْماءِ هؤُلاءِ>> (Inform Me of the names of these) whom you were directed to bring into existence—meaning, were the Names directed [to you]? Did you glorify Me and sanctify Me by them, since you claimed that you glorify Me with My praise and sanctify Me? The angels said: <<لا عِلْمَ لَنا>> (We have no knowledge). Then He said to Adam: <<أَنْبِئْهُمْ بِأَسْمائِهِمْ>> (Inform them of their names). Thus, He made him a master (أستاذا) for them. He taught them all the Names, and they knew then that he was a vicegerent *from* Allah on His earth, not a vicegerent for a predecessor.

Then it continued to be received by a perfect one from a perfect one until it reached the Greatest Master, Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), who was known for his prophethood while Adam was between water and clay. The water is for the existence of the sons, and the clay is the existence of Adam. He (peace and blessings be upon him) was given the comprehensive words (جوامع الكلم), just as Adam was given all the Names. Then Allah taught him the Names that He taught Adam, so he knew the knowledge of the first and the last. Thus, Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) was the greatest vicegerent and the greatest Imam, and his community (أمته) was <<خَيْرَ أُمَّةٍ أُخْرِجَتْ لِلنَّاسِ>> (the best community brought forth for mankind). Allah placed his inheritors in the stations of the prophets and messengers, permitting them independent legal reasoning (الاجتهاد) in rulings. This is legislation derived from the report of the Lawgiver. Thus, every *mujtahid* (one who exercises independent reasoning) is correct, just as every prophet is infallible. Allah obligated them with this so that this community might obtain a share of legislation and establish a footing therein. None preceded them except their Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him).

The scholars of this community, the preservers of the Muhammadan Law (الشريعة المحمدية), will be gathered in the ranks of the prophets, not in the ranks of the nations. They are witnesses over mankind, and this is a clear text regarding their uprightness. There is no messenger but that beside him is one scholar from this community, or two, or three, or whatever number. Every scholar among them holds the degree of mastership (الأستاذية) in the science of forms (الرسوم), states (الأحوال), stations (المقامات), stages (المنازل), and spiritual descents (المنازلات), until the matter culminates in the Seal of the Saints (خاتم الأولياء), the Seal of the Muhammadan *Mujtahids*, until it reaches the General Seal, who is the Spirit of Allah and His Word. He is the last student and the last master for those who take from him. He and his companions from the community of Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) will die in a single moment (نفس واحد) by a pleasant wind that takes them from beneath their armpits. They will find delight in it, like the delight of the sleepy person whom wakefulness has exhausted and sleep overtakes at dawn, which the Lawgiver called *al-'usaylah* (the little honey) due to its sweetness. They will find a delight in death whose measure cannot be estimated. Then there will remain the rabble, like the scum of the torrent, resembling beasts, and upon them the Hour will be established.

The Trustworthy Spirit, Gabriel (peace be upon him), was the teacher and master of the messengers. When he revealed to Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), he would hasten with the Quran before his revelation was concluded to him, so that Allah might know by the state that Allah had taken charge of his teaching from the specific aspect that the angel was unaware of. Allah made the angel descending with the revelation a veiled form (صورة حجابية). Then the Exalted commanded him in what He revealed: <<لا تُحَرِّكْ به لِسانَكَ لِتَعْجَلَ به>> (Do not move your tongue with it to hasten it), as an act of etiquette toward his Master. For he (peace and blessings be upon him) says: "Indeed, Allah disciplined me, and He perfected my discipline." This confirms that Allah took charge of his teaching Himself. Then He said, also confirming that: <<إِنَّ عَلَيْنا جَمْعَهُ وقُرْآنَهُ فَإِذا قَرَأْناهُ فَاتَّبِعْ قُرْآنَهُ ثُمَّ إِنَّ عَلَيْنا بَيانَهُ>> (Indeed, upon Us is its collection and its recitation. So when We have recited it, follow its recitation. Then indeed, upon Us is its clarification). He mentioned none but Himself, and attributed it only to Himself. No mention of anyone other than Allah was permissible in this definition. And thus came the wording of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) in his saying: "Indeed, Allah disciplined me, and He perfected my discipline." He mentioned none but Allah, making no reference to an intermediary or an angel, for Allah defined Himself to us in this way. Then we found that this flows through his inheritors among the scholars in every group—I mean, the scholars of forms (علماء الرسوم) and the scholars of hearts (علماء القلوب). Thus, the return of teaching, whether through an intermediary or without one, is to the Lord. For that reason, the angel said: <<وما نَتَنَزَّلُ إِلَّا بِأَمْرِ رَبِّكَ>> (And we do not descend except by the command of your Lord). The form of teaching has thus become clear to you from this section. Furthermore, the Exalted legislated for every master that he should not see any superiority for himself over his student, and that the rank of mastership should not veil him from the knowledge of his own self and his servitude (عبوديته). This is the principle to which reference is made. <<والله يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the Truth, and He guides to the Way).

### "The Twentieth Section" from the Treasuries of Generosity (خزائن الجود)

This is the treasury of Divine Rulings (الأحكام الإلهية), conventional laws (النواميس الوضعية), and Divine Laws (الشرعية). And that the Exalted Allah has two paths in His revelation to the hearts of His servants concerning what He legislates for every community.

One path is by sending the Trustworthy Spirit, named Gabriel, or whoever among the angels, to a servant of Allah. That servant is then called a Messenger (رسولا) and a Prophet (نبيا) because of this descent upon him, and those to whom he is sent must believe in him and in what he brought from his Lord. The other path is through the hands of the rational person of his time, whom Allah inspires within his self, and the Holy Divine Spirit (الروح الإلهي القدسي) breathes into his heart during a period when messengers are absent (فترة من الرسل) and paths are obscured (درس من السبل). Allah inspires him in that situation with what is necessary for the common good (المصالح), such as the preservation of life, property, and chastity, due to the jealousy (الغيرة) Allah instilled in the animal souls (النفوس الحيوانية). He paves a way for them, which, if they follow it, leads them back to their common good, so they feel safe concerning their families, lives, and property. He sets limits (حدودا) for them in this, instills fear and caution in them, gives them hope, and commands them to obey what he has commanded and forbidden, and not to oppose him. He specifies deterrents (زواجر) such as killing, beating, and fines, to curb the corruption and dispersion that might occur, and encourages the unification of the word. The Exalted Allah rewards him for this during the periods of absence (أصحاب الفترات).

However, in a community where there is a messenger, or which is under the address of a messenger, this is forbidden for him, and it is forbidden for him to depart from the Law (شرع) of the Messenger. This conventional method (الطريقة الوضعية), which wisdom demands, has not appeared in any species except specifically the human species, due to its creation upon the Form. Thus, he finds within himself a Divine power that calls him to legislate for the common good. If someone other than him—namely, the Messenger—has legislated it, he must continuously support and pave the way for his community and what that Messenger established for them, and clarify for them what was hidden from them in his message due to the deficiency of their understanding. If he does not do this, despite his ability, he will remain in decline until the Day of Resurrection, just as it is said concerning the Imam who leads the prayer while knowing that behind him is one more deserving of the imamate than he, yet he does not put him forward but leads himself: he remains in decline until the Day of Resurrection, unless that superior person puts him forward and he leads by his command. Like the prayer of Abu Bakr with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), and the prayer of Abd al-Rahman ibn Awf with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) when he arrived, having missed one *rak'a*, and led the prayer because the time was running out. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) arrived when they had prayed one *rak'a*, so he prayed behind him, thanked them for what they had done, and said, "You have done well." Were it not that the Lawgiver confirmed the ruling of the *mujtahid* among the scholars of this community, no ruling would be established for him.

### [That the Scholars of Allah are of Ranks in their Reception of Divine Knowledge]

Know that the scholars of Allah are of ranks in their reception of Divine Knowledge (العلم الإلهي). Among them are those who took knowledge of Allah *from* Allah, and these are those to whom it was said: "Know that He is one God." Among them are those who took knowledge of Allah through contemplation (نظر) and inference (استدلال). These are those for whom Allah established proofs and signs <<فِي الْآفاقِ وفي أَنْفُسِهِمْ>> (in the horizons and within themselves), and commanded them to contemplate that <<حَتَّى يَتَبَيَّنَ لَهُمْ أَنَّهُ الْحَقُّ>> (until it becomes clear to them that it is the Real).
